reviewText:
Early Access Review

Great for those that enjoy a true sandbox RPG with plenty of swordfighting and a large amount of city-building available.

Updating this review now that I have more time dedicated to write it.

This is going to be a very patchwork comparison of Kenshi to other games that a potential buyer may, or may not, already own, and I will detail my personal experiences for you all to read, or not. :D

So, Kenshi is a squad-based RPG (think of Dawn of War 2, but each individual character in the squad has their own D&D-style character sheet) with some RTS elements (specifically the capability of building structures and researching technologies to unlock new structures, items, and upgrades) that puts a strong emphasis on open-ended gameplay (many puns to be had playing a sandbox game set in the desert).
The Kenshi-verse (name of the world chosen by several members of the community, including myself) is an original creation with influences from the Edo Period in Japan (weapons and armor models are influenced by the samurai of that time, and it has been confirmed there will be no weapons relying on gunpowder or later technologies, just pure swordplay with some ranged combat and unarmed combat to come in the future).

You, as a new player, get to choose from one of multiple starting points (i.e. a trader, retired soldier, etc.), and each starting point essentially grants the player a specific character(s) that have certain advantages and disadvantages.
Keep in mind that there is a very strong emphasis on open-ended gameplay, so any of these starting points can be molded and shaped to create the character(s) that you will enjoy most.
Regardless of the starting point chosen, your character will start at, or close to, rock bottom with little more than a rusty blade and the clothes on your back.
The point of this is that your character(s) will grow and gain experience in the numerous skills and attributes (the # of skills and attributes currently available (17) appear to be about half of what is planned for the final release) by performing activities that are related to that skill.
Things such as carrying a heavy load or swinging a heavy weapon in combat will improve your Strength, whereas wielding a lighter weapon will increase Dexterity.
Even at the farm, crafting weapons/armor, picking locks, or simply running laps around town will increase their corresponding skills (btw, each of these actions I listed apply to unique skills).

Once your starting point is chosen, you are then introduced to a rather in-depth character creation screen.
This character creation screen allows you to choose either gender as well as modify hair, eyes, skin, muscle tone, height, weight, girth, bust, and most importantly, facial hair.
After creating your character, it is possible to find an NPC called the Plastic Sugeon (should be at least 1 in every NPC town) that will allow you to modify any character in your squad using this character creation screen (it goes without saying this emphasizes the sandbox part even more).

After you're satisfied with your character, then explore the Kenshi-verse to your heart's content!
I say this because the current world (which is nothing but desert) has been confirmed to be less than 1/4 of the actual Kenshi-verse, AND this new world map is currently in the works as I am typing this.

Some basic control shortcuts to help new players get started:
Shift+LMB stack of multiple items = Allows player to pick up whole stacks of items
Hold RMB over any character = Brings up a list of all the actions that can be performed on this character (NPC or PC)

The rest of the basic controls are either given to you at the start of gameplay or can be found, and rebound, in the Options -> Controls menu.

Another HUGE part of Kenshi that I haven't even touched yet is modding.
Kenshi has been developed from its core to allow extensive modding so that each player can have an even more unique experience.

To my knowledge, there are mods available that:
Add new weapons/armor to the Kenshi-verse
Add dialogue, and dialogue trees, to NPCs (which bring a large variety of things from quests to mercenaries, and I think its also possible to edit existing dialogue to read in other languages)
Add structures to Kenshi and modify their functional components (things such as a structure's capability to receive an item to Input and produce an Output from it or to allow the mass Storage of a certain item)
Modify components of NPCs in various ways (things such as # of bandits in each squad, add entire NPC towns, change ownership of an existing town from one faction to another)

Among many, many other mods that have already been produced by the Kenshi community.
There are also numerous, well-detailed tutorials available for any user to learn how to mod Kenshi in less than a day's worth of time.

Anyone that has read this far should go to:
www.lofigames.com
and check out all of the information available there.
Be sure to click on the Roadmap tab at the top to see everything that is planned and when it will be implemented.
Oh, and you should totally join in the conversations on the Forums (I'm on there a lot ;D).
Chris, THE dev and programmer of Kenshi, also posts regular updates to his twitter page as well as screenshots at:
www.twitter.com/lofigames

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Kenshi is a fun game, but there are a few deal-breakers that I hope get future attention:

-No way to recruit new guys (in the latest version) without forking over thousands at a time. There is maybe one character I've encountered that is willing to join you, and he costs 6000 in game currency.

-And you're gonna need some help, because the game is irritatingly difficult when beginning. I know it is supposed to be a challenge, but the only way to level your guy is to follow around a patrol which may or may not encounter hostile groups. Even then, expect to get only a few hits in before the patrol wipes out the enemy.

-Getting your character to attack is a hassle. Right clicking works some of the time. Other times you have to hold right click over an enemy and tell your character to attack him.

-The staggering animation after being hit often leaves you open to another attack, which can stagger you again. Kinda lame considering that...

-The punishment for losing a fight is way too severe. When you get KO'd you can be waiting upwards of 300+ seconds to have your guy wake up. After bandaging yourself, you must limp/walk to the nearest city to sleep if you don't have the materials to make a camp bed. Getting to the nearest city can take long enough, but sleeping till recovery takes waaaaaaaaaaayyyyyyyy too long considering how the rest of this recovery process goes...

-If you do make a camp bed, because limping to the nearst town takes too long, I hope you don't mind spending the night with bandits or dogs, who will stand over you until you wake up. And then kill you. And if it was dogs instead of bandits, then you might as well make a new game, because they're not going anywhere after you get KO'd.

-Poor optimization in its current state.

A lot of people enjoy the game, and for good reason. Just be warned that you might find this game to be pretty tedious, frustrating, and possibly unplayable. I'd say to wait a while before buying.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Allow me to say this: If you do NOT have a large amount of patience, this game is not for you, at least not yet.

Kenshi is a wonderful game, I've sunk days and days of my time into this Early Access, and I love it. The feeling of being horribly puny in a world that seeks to better itself , and then becoming strong enough to crush the world is a feeling only comparable to doing the same thing in your everyday life. That is Kenshi. You write your story, you act it out. Crush your opposition, or bankrupt their pocketbooks? Annihalate the bandits, or help them take over cities? You are, or will, be asked these questions over and over.

Another of the great things about Kenshi is that it takes the motto of Urbanprophet; Unfair, Random, Brutality; and takes it to the next level. The game is exceedingly Unfair. You will probably lose men. That one-man army you really want to be? Well, he's lying on the ground, dying slowly after being attacked by 30 bandits. It's a painfully wonderful experience. It is Brutal, the enemies do not go easy on you- You just killed those Samurai's buddies? The entire faction wants you dead now, and you have armies of some of the strongest people in the game after you. Oh, now you can watch your 12 man squad rot slowly on the dusty desert. It is Random. No two people are the same unless they're twins or you made them that way. Every combat experience is utterly random. Yes, there's SOME consistency, as a soldier with 40 combat skill and 40 Defense skill probably won't get taken out by a couple of hungry bandits, but lucky hits DO happen. It can be frustrating to see that up-armored beast get KO'd by some thugs with sticks, but even SAS Operatives get shot by untrained Guerillas.

You almost have to be a masochist to play Kenshi. Almost.

Unfortunately, the game is consistently buggy, whether it be from minor graphics glitches caused by saving/loading, upto pathing issues that can be game-breaking. It's painful to be forced to watch your men die on the sands, and the fact that the game can't recognize your men are all pretty much dead and allow you to start a new game is a little offensive. The lack of a Return to Main Menu" button is a little disconcerting in itself.

In addition to that
date: it lacks a lot of diversity in its content. The "Music" is virtually nonexistent. It almost makes it difficult to want to play the game. Almost. Weaponry and Armor for your characters has a distinctly Asian flair
recommended: but doesn't deviate far from that. Combat animations are virtually the same for all people and weapons
hoursPlayed: and Melee combat is currently all there is. You buy Mercenaries. You kill things. You might even build a base. It's easy to become disillusioned if you aren't patient
voteText: or a good role-player.\n\nAt the moment
helpfulPercent: the one game I can compare this to is a 3D Version of Caravaneer
votesHelpful: without guns
votesTotal: and that is a very good thing. What the developer here tries to pull off is an extensive trade network with fluctuating prices; towns that have surplus stocks and will pay desperately with whatever they can to get what they're on a shortage of. That doesn't happen.\n\nDespite all of its flaws

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I don't write reviews, infact this is the only one i've done or probably will do because this is my favorite game on steam.

Pros:
-The ability to customize units is what sold me on this. I've always loved being able to make my own stories and characters within a game and it works well in this.
-There is always a new story to tell with your character(s). Example: Getting kidnapped by cannibals and barely escaping(if at all), then building/training an army and taking your revenge on them.
-You can mod the game, however it isn't the most straight foward and there are not too many made for it yet. You can find some on the nexus, if you know what you are doing.
-Updates. The makers of this game DO release updates and patches even if they do take a while, adding new content that stack layers of gameplay. If you do some research you can see the guy who made this game loves it and truely wants to see it finished (even hired more people to help build it).

Cons:
-Like I said, the updates can take a long time to come out but they do.
-Some people experience bugs and crashes while others do not.
-Once you get your characters up to a certain level in combat it may become a little too easy. However, they are adding new stuff to keep it challenging.

If you enjoy these games you may enjoy this one:
X-com, Age of Empires, Mount and blade

Over-all I give this game a 8.5/10 in the experimental beta build. Like a fine wine, it gets better with time.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've seen people say that Kenshi is a RTS game but it's not just that. Kenshi can be played as RTS where you lead troops but also you can play it as RPG controling 1-2 characters and make their stories or you can play the game as a town builder.

Positive aspects of game:

Freedom: The best feature i belive is the freedom you have in game do whatever you like, kill whoever you like, you can be a thief, a killer, just a wanderer or whatever else you like to do.
Realism: Maybe the graphics are not yet the best and the animations a bit glichy but the game mechanics are realistic, every single unit-character has hit points for each part of his body. Head, Torso, Stomach and another 4 for 2 legs and 2 arms, if you get badly wounded you might fall in a coma and never wake up, or wake up after days you might even lose your hand or leg forever, and offcourse if you die is permadeath.
Mods: The game can be moded for further fun.

Negative aspects of game:

Badly writen pathfinding: The pathfinding i think is the worst thing the game has it needs to be rewriten and fixed asap. The units-characters tend to stuck between buildings because they dont know where to go.
Crashes: Random crashes can happen I also noticed that sometimes after a crash the game gets corupted and it keeps crashing more.
Bugs, Gliches and Low FPS: The game is in early state since Octomber 2012 they keep adding stuff but the game is not stable I believe they need to make a stable release and fix those errors before they put more stuff in.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

In 2016 I can safely say that abandoned games get updated at a faster rate.

You know those games that sound very, very good? Kenshi is one of those games.

Unfortunately, Kenshi has sounded very good for a long time now and hasn't actually had much added to it. You'll spend most of your time watching a character walk from place to place while keeping the game on fast forward.

But perhaps the combat is redeeming, you say? Nope, you fast forward that too. In fact, there's very little reason to not just play this game on fast forward the entire time. It's basically a watching simulator.

But the fun doesn't end there. The forums are rather heavily censored and anything that isn't praise toward the developers is deleted and followed by a ban. As of now, I don't think people who don't own kenshi can even post there. This is clearly just an attempt to censor the forum more heavily.

So, why should you consider kenshi? Well, if you like games that have been in development for years with minimal progress it's right up your alley! If you like games where you hit an endgame with almost nothing to do it's perfect as well!

And if you go to the forum for tips you'll be told to make your own game(Within kenshi)." Yup

reviewText:
Early Access Review

TL;DR:

It's a true to the word Alpha so it crashes and there are clearly parts of the game that do not work yet. However, the greater vision for what the game will be is clear and it clearly is going to be a game of epic proportions with plenty of replayability.

Full Review:

The game lets you play as you wish. Want to be a BA swordsman with an elite squad of goons? Done. Want to be tader making your way through the waste lands? Done. Want to settle your own town and be the greatest blacksmith in the land? Done. Want to by a sleezy tief in the night? Done.

The game has a fantastic engine that allows you level your character based on the actions he takes. If you fight a lot, he will become better at fighting. If you run around a lot he becomes a faster runner. Carry heavy things - builds strength. Unit growth is very organic, though you can also setup tasks to help power level guys as well.

The main game, which is not completed yet, will allow you to effectively build your own clan. You will be able to raid other towns and even take them over. If you do not want to run your own clan with towns then you can try your hand at being a merchinary in one of the many conflicts that will going on around the map.

The game is also introducing multiple races and ambient creatures that will kick your butt!!

All the fun stuff aside there are some drawbacks. At the time of the post this is still very much in Alpha. The game crashes regularly, your save files become outdated or unable to be retrieved often, and your are constantly tantilzed by the features you can see but not use. For an Alpha it is pretty playable though and the dev makes balancing changes every so often so that the game remains fun to play.

If you cannot handle losing your entire saved game or getting randomly kicked this is not the time to buy, wait for the proper release. If you can't wait to be a steampunk samuri in a desert wasteland then by all means get it!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As it stands now in Early Access, Kenshi shows a lot of promise as a hit game.  I play with experimental patches enabled, and I get to see the latest additions to the game- bugs included.  If you're a fan of participating in the course of a game's development, your input can- and will greatly impact- the course of the game's development.  This is one everyone should get onboard for!

For starters, I'd like to thank members of the development team and their forum moderators for being so involved in discussion.  Many of the threads created in both the Steam forums and the Lo-Fi Game forums end up with answers from members of the team, and what you say can and will make an impact.  To be able to get in touch with someone heading up the game and recieve a personal response is both uplifting and noteworthy.  For me, this game gets high marks for this level of involvement in the community, as for many other development teams, such close coordination has been too much to ask for.

On to gameplay; Kenshi is an interesting mesh of Real Time Strategy, base-building, caravaneer mechanics, where you have many choices of how to make your living.

In terms of RTS, you can choose from or mod your own Game Start that allows you to pick a set of characters or character, and enter the game world to begin an adventure.  Mechanics are simple:  Using the Numpad or your mouse, you select your character and order them with a click to move.  You can do this to adjust your active navigation, taking detours where you need to, or you can rely upon the surprisingly competent pathfinding AI, which can take you from one side of the map to the other appropriately if you let it, though sometimes patches make this feature a bit fragile.  There is no first person or third person play, it's really a game of watching and hoping you've trained your guys enough that they can handle themselves in a combat situation.

Your life revolves around your squad, and what you choose to do with them.  You will, at some point, be attacked, and you will have to fight back, so it's best to train up your brave men and women any way you can to keep yourself above the frey.  At lower levels, combat can be hard, if not embarassing.  You can be slaughtered and not even see a rational reason why (other than your guys just suck at swinging a weapon).  Currently, swordsmanship is the big deal going around, granted the namesake of Mortal Kombat character Kenshi (literally; swordsman), though turrets have been added to the game and ranged weapons are expected in the future (no muskets or revolvers, though modding will make that quite easy to do once ranged mechanics are in, so look forward to it!).

The real fun in Kenshi is in what you decide to do with yourself once you're in.  Bounty Hunting, Raiding, Murder and Looting are all part of the possibilities, but more than that, you have the option to become the target of such things.

One of the lifestyles you can fall into is a sort of wandering trader, or caravaneer.  Basically, you throw backpacks on a few of your squad members, put the best weapons in the hands of your best muscle, and send your people from town to town crating goods for sale.  Each town hosts a unique set of prices for certain goods; Chainmail can be worth 76% of it's base value one place, and 130% of that value in another, allowing you to invest a lot of money that makes a good return.  All that matters is that you don't oversell to the extent that it breaks their bank.  Being a traveling merchant grants many benefits, and it's a good way to get a leg up in a new game, as running builds strength and athletics, which aid in fighting, running and hauling later on in your lifecycle.

Alternatively, the player can create their own town and have the merchants come to them.  Now, this is a fantastic feature, the construction mechanics of the game are pretty solid, even in it's current state.  If you see a man-made structure in the game, chances are that you'll be able to build it.  You start with a decent shack or house, build a research table, set up a farm, and start work on learning new things and stockpiling new resources.  It takes a while for a town to become self-sustaining, but when it does, you can feel free to hermit it up.  You basically have the same tools at your disposal as the developers do when it comes to construction, and you can make the same quality of layout if your talent allows.  Setting up shops and resource centers allows trade and storage, and building walls and turrets keeps out any unsavory individuals that you might find in the wasteland.  Yes, sometimes a world without borders can be a dangerous one.

If being a nice guy minding his own business doesn't suit you, or if the Holy Nation stumbles upon your town of peaceful Shek peoples, becoming a more hostile force is also an option.  You even get the option to be a little creative...  Building cages and holding areas for the people you knock out on the battlefield gives you the option to take prisoners, and there'll certainly be more that you can do with this mechanic as the game progresses.  The Role Playing options offered in this game exceed those offered in many others, and the style of gameplay isn't just fun, but addictive.

With this said, there are a few downsides to the game that you would probably want to know about before buying.

For one, Kenshi seems to be set-in-stone in terms of what lore it will follow.  This is no problem to most people, but to some, it's pretty concentrated on one Apocalyptic Eastern theme.  I've found that the concept the game follows is a bit rigid, as it celebrates the way of Eastern warriors, yet, leaves out the opportunity to equip shields for added defense, neglects any Western-style weaponry (no Claymore, Gladius, Spear, or Cutlass styles), and the story behind it all can be a bit confusing, at times, with regard to finding a point in it all.

What bugs me about the weapon variety is partly explained by the fact that I'm more familiar with Western swordsmanship than Eastern, and I feel that these arts are something that the game is missing out on in a great opportunity.  As it stands, there are a limited number of weapon classes and they're pretty much wide-spread, though manufactured by different companies" and distributed across the world.  There's a lot of room for far more variety

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is seriously one of the coolest games I have played.  The whole game is based around you and your sqaud, wait...  Scratch that...  This game hates you...  You aren't the biggest baddest guy in the world, you aren't going to be able to defeat an army by yourself, you can't do shiznit in this game...  Unless you work for it...

The only way to get anywhere in this game is to work for it.  If you want to be the strongest man in the game, you have to train long and hard.  If you want a giant city, you have to get the resources, and build it by hand.

One of the coolest parts about this game is the work mechanics.  Say you want one guy to be your engineer and build all the buildings and such.  Well, you aren't always going to be building things, are you?  No, so you set engineering as your permanent job, which means that if there is a building job going on, then he will do it.  And then his second job may be researching, so when there is no building going on, he is researching more buildings.

This game may be an alpha, but I have played 25 hours and it seems like there is still more to research and build.  There is no sound, but the Torchlight 1 soundtrack sounds pretty good in the background!  So yeah, if you want a game where you aren't the biggest baddest guy in existence, get this game...

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Kenshi as an idea has taken me in a way that most largely produced titles haven't been able to.  Having played just above 80 hours I feel I can write a decent review of this game.  Having bought the game almost a year and half ago and seeing short progress I was worried; however, it's good to see that there are dedicated people still out there not just trying to get their quick cash and move on.

Kenshi offers you a vast empty (which is good)  desert world where you must fend for yourself and that's as far as the story will take you at this moment in time.   The choice is yours, what do you do? Read a bunch of f**king guides is what you do, or at least myself, but I digress.  Throughout gameplay you must make decisions where to incoporate your time....as in...do I take my only 2 soldiers to escort my 3 traders to a town to sell Ale/chainmail/katanas/fragaxes/medkits/etc, or do i keep 1 soldier at the outpost guarding 2 of those traders while they continue to produce while only sending 1 soldier and 1 trader....which could possibly be attacked by a multitude of people (have fun with that population setting!)  At the same time you must research and dedicate certain squadmates to certain jobs where they will become more proficient as such.  Efficiency is key in Kenshi especially when you just start your outpost.
Base building is relatively smooth with only minor bugs which can be avoided by a quick save and reload  (applies to entire gameplay as well), and although there aren't uses for many of the items currently ingame besides monetary value there is much promise for the future.  The core buildings on the other hand are useful and there are many of them with industry like processes to advance your small faction as such.

As far as skills go Kenshi has many of the same skills you find in any other RPG game out there, the difference is that these skills actually have a real-time effect in gameplay.  What i mean by that is that if you have low strength, good luck carrying that backpack full of steel, wearing durable heavy armors, and larger weapons all while slowing you down becoming cannibal food in the process......AND making your Attack say (-14) because you dont know what you're doing with said weapon......fool.
So the game hits on the saying practice makes perfect." in a nutshell in all skill-like aspects.  The unfortunate side is that there are still a considerable amount of skills "greyed" out not finished yet (awesome when finished)  but do not let that take away from this light of a game in this dark re-hashed titled clone world of ours.  It's EA and for as imperative as the devs made the skills (not just stat raises) is something fresh

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Actual Review after the first chunk of Text.

I've been reading quite a few Negative Reviews about this game complaining about how it's bugged and how slow the development on this is, though I do not find this negative, especially since this game Is in Early Access and in it's Alpha Stage. People complain about games not being Bugfree while they are still in Early Access, which is meant to help the developers to improve the game by finding said bugs and reporting them to them. About the development being slow though, yes i have to agree the development is quite slow, with the game being in Early Access / Alpha for over 5 years now, though they do release updates quite regularly most of the time. well now that this rant is over on to the Actual Review.

Kenshi is a Squad Based Open World Role playing Game that is currently in it's Alpha (for over 5 years now).

The Game in it's current version has already quite a lot to offer, especially with some of the bigger updates still coming up. The Development on this game can be quite slow since it is being produced by a small Team consisting of 6 Actual members and a few Volunteers and Freelancers.

Positives about the Game:

+ You currently have quite a Huge map that you can explore and build your base on with more and different Land to be released in a future update.

+ You aren't god in this game, you are a basic human (or group of humans) that has to survive in the desert (maybe other places in later updates), not more, not less.

+ The game is actively being Developed even if it may be slow, the game has been receiving updates for over 5 years now so I'll doubt that the studio has any plans on abandoning it.

+ Has great music (not too much different music but great music)

Negatives:

- You won't get a full on Role Playing feel yet as the game is still in development.

- A bit hard to get into at first

- Kinda slow development though i don't blame them, I have enough respect for them for even trying to make a game like this.

- Obviously, you will experience Bugs since it's in Early Access.

Final Verdict:

This Game is already great and shows potential to become one of my favorite Squad Based RPGs. If you are a fan of games like these go ahead and buy it, but be aware that the Game is still in Early Access / Alpha which means you won't get a full on Finished Game" experience. Early Access is here to help Developers find bugs and help them find ideas not for actually playing the game early. So if you want to help the Development (even if it is quite slow sometimes) go ahead and get it. But if you want a full game experience wait until the Game gets out of Early Access somewhen."

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nKenshi is a squad based open world post apocolyptic RPG, but you probably knew that already. When I forst bought this game like maybe one odd years ago it was rough, but I could see the potential and managed to enjoy almost 50 hours of it. I was coutious to recommend at the time because I wasnt sure if development would be dropped or not seeing as it was slow and economically unstable. Recently I checked back and was thrilled to see development is continuing and significant progress is being made. With these doubts out of the picture I am confident in recommending this game. It has alot of charm and is well thought out, A truly free RPG.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Kenshi Is a fantastic idea but is one of those gruesomely Beta/Alpha games that we all know steam to be a hub for.

There is still alot of work to be done on stability (The experimental version is very prone to crashing) and aspects of the game are still in progress of being developed. So if you have a short temperament you may wish to wait till it's finished.

That being said it's very difficult drawing yourself away for it. Creating your charaters from hair to feet then training them up in whatever respected fields you wish them to delve into from farming to swordplay to thievery . Beautifully thought out landscapes and structures to explore and the abusive bandits that wander there. Once you make enough of a living from selling your scraps to traders in towns, you can even build your own settlement from scrach and make a town of your own.

Hopefully if and when the game is finished being fiddled with, this can be an amazing game giving players the full freedom every RPG deserves.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The Game:

Kenshi is a game that can't be catagorized. It's a beautiful, sword-punk blend of RPG, RTS, and to some extent a city builder/Sims-style survival game where you cater to basic needs. The demo does the game little justice, and many people who rate it poorly probably never experienced the transition of this game into what it is now. The developers are committed to creating a living world, and tailors an RPG-style game where you are no hero. Even if you choose a start that makes you top dog when it comes to the scum of Kenshi, you bite the bullet.

Pros:

-Multiple ways/genres" to play.

-Multiple settings for adjusting the difficulty

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\n155 hours of play and climbing, this game is a great combination of player punishment and self driver objective gameplay. Do I want to farm? Do I want to fight? how do I know I'll even survie this fight? que the lone medic picking up their kin from the floor and dusting them off before the scavengers arrive. Such a great game but not recommended for people used to being spoon fed virtual achievements. This game is a slow crawl to the mountain top, clenching your teeth the whole journey, only to know that one mistake will throw you back down again.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As I write this I lay unconcious with my face in the desert sands after being mobbed on a lone trade run by hungry desert bandits.  They taught me not to run over burdened.
Kenshi is Warband+1.
It will take time to get to grips with the UI - which is improved from some of the youtube videos I watched before buying it.
I'm playing it on an i5 1.8mHz laptop with nvidia 710M, and it insits on using the cruddy inel graphics card.  But this doesn;t affect gameplay for me.
Returning to the desert to wait out my survival coma.  On the plus side I am not bleeding.  Though the bandits took all my inventory - including a sword which I aqquired from a samarai who was erm, sleeping face down in the desert!

Love the game, give it some time.

If you like warband you'll love this.  RPG/business/hack/slash.

Though all I've done so far is get beat up and turn in a dying man for a bounty :)

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nKenshi Is one of my favorite games of all time. The free roam combined with the ability to play however you please is great. The sword fighting is smooth and feels like a action movie. Your always determined to get more powerful so your rarely left wandering around woudering what to do next. The game has multiple starting back storys to choose from and after you spend a good bit of time completing those you can mod the game quite easily. The ability to create and mod the entire world of kenshi after watching a 10 minute youtube video is amazing. Ive spent close to a hundred hours just modding kenshi the way I please. Anything in kenshi I think is to hard or easy I can fix. You can also create custom armor,weapons and pretty much change the entire world in anyway you want. I only wish more games would give there community the ability to do this so easily. Kenshi gets a 10 out of 10 in my book.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've been following this game since before it was even on Desura, and I was excited for the longest time. I waited and waited and waited for significant changes to the playability of the game and have had a lot of fun in Kenshi.

Sadly, after so many years I have to say that I do NOT recommend this game. Until the creator decides that fixing longlasting bugs and upgrading the animations, graphics, and UI are more important than adding broken features like slavery and thievery, I will continue to not recommend this game. The fact that he has made so much less progress on this game than others I have followed for the longest time is honestly depressing.

I don't know if this game will ever reach the potential I hoped it would. Stay away.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game provides all the elements I look for in a game if any of the following apply to you, you will enjoy this.

1. Micromanagement; As your group grows the functions for each grow and multi tasking stays fresh, you wont go long before a bandit attack. There's always work to do, training to be done the tasks never end. Making your party run laps in their precious down time, training your combat skills on captured prisoners, producing gear or buildind/researching the list goes on.

2.RPG; Each character has its own stats, the time it takes to get anything to level 20+ is abit time consuming, but it gives a sense of satisfaction as you make another character a mighty warrior in the wasteland.

3.City Building; Build your own city! it takes time, but building your own utopia complete with shops, workshops, homes, outposts, defense walls, mounted crossbows, the only limit is how long your willing to spend preparing your characters for the coming construction.

4.Crafting; At first its more about gathering gear from fallen foe's outside the city gates, but once you begin teching and producing your own gear, a high quality katana compared to a rusty one is a beautiful sight, you can also produce all the raw materials needed for self preservation which is tougher, but for some more rewarding.

5.Diplomacy; Want to be friends with a certain group of bandits? Heal some of their fallen kin, eventually they will stop attacking you and come to your aide. (This takes time, I also assume in the future there will be many diplomatic aspects, but have yet to be added).

6.Permanent Death; Think your starter character is a badass? wrong. Each unit becomes precious, you grow attatched as they become valueable, and then at the worst moment a critical strike leaves them stranded far from a safe location, too far to carry safely without a character with strength above 30... you keep watching hoping the bleeding stops and he'll enter a recovery coma but no his status switches to dying" and you panic
date: time to decide if your capable enough to make the rescue
hoursPlayed: a large enough band of bandits/cannibals could strike you all down
voteText: and end your game. (Also note
helpfulPercent: the cannibals will take your people prisoner and amount of time you have to wait for a distraction is FOREVER
votesHelpful: but its great).\n\n7.Travel/Relocation; Making it town to town in the begining is thrilling
votesTotal: as your group grows and you safely reach each destination
votesFunny: perhaps traveling with a caravan or a squad of UC/HO troops for safety

column16: the town you're in could be overrun. (I've seen it happen twice lol)\n\n8.Huge Replay Value; Start in a new town

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nSo, I love the idea of this game as I have played a lot of games very much like this one. Lately I've been getting extremely annoyed by bugs and such. Bandits's and whoever just running through my walls even though I've checked countless times for holes in wall, characters just stop moving and either have to pick the up with another character or reload the game, I read that you can steal from stores now but the system makes absolutely no sense, characters not following commands get picked up by someone else in hopes of making them work  again in turn making both of them get stuck, and one of the biggest is the engineer. Queueing someone to be a perm engineer is practically worthless, mine keeps trying to do the most random things such as open a door then run to fabric box then just do whatever he wants to. The bug with characters not following commands is getting very annoying because I dont like reloading my game every 5 minutes. Stealing from stores is extremely hard and it's also kinda... what?? You have to KILL the store owner, not only that but you also have to carry him away from the store. Then you still have to wait about 6 hours (game time) to be able to take from the counter without actually paying for it (stealing). The update said talking to the character would be trading whereas accessing the counter would be stealing but this literally doesn't even work and this update was posted very long ago. The last bug that really ticks me off is bandits literally just WALKING THROUGH MY WALLS,.. So after the huge amount of time i spend walking around with 1 engineer and 1 person to pick him up whenever he stops responding (This is the way you have to build walls like I said the engineer's pathfinding is worthless right now) the bandits simply walk through my max level walls... I have checked to make sure these are actually bugs and not personal fault. Right now I don't recommend this game because from what I saw the wall bug has been around for almost 3 years at least. MAYBE after this update in march I will change my mind but these bugs must be fixed or this game will remain unplayable. Now then... time to play some Kenshi. I love the idea of this game please fix these bugs!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I played this game for over a year on Desura before it came to Steam and let me just say, if you're looking for a fun tactical-strategy-rpg-citybuilding extravaganza, look no further. Kenshi has the most open playability of any game I've played since Ultima Online. If you want to develop a trading outpost into a bustling town, you can. If you just want to be a bunch of nomad bandits, have at it!

Pros

-Such Depth! Much Fun!

-Deep Character Progression

-Develop your faction into whatever you want from honored to infamous and enjoy the faction effects it has toward every other group in the game.

-Awesome Music, but it gets a little repetitive after hours.

-Fun Crafting and Construction System!

Cons

-There's a bit of a learning curve and

-Unrealistic combat. The best way to grind skills is to walk fights and just kite the enemies to a town to level up your fighting which gets monotonous and doesn't make any sense. Were I a bandit, I doubt I would chase some nobodies to my doom, but that's just me.

Early Access Review

(This review was created on March 3rd, 2014. It may become obsolete sooner or later.)

This game has potential. It really does. It's a sandbox in a steampunk neo-feudal Japan-esque setting. The dev has not clarified what's going on and probably won't tell us for a very long time. I bought this before it was released on Steam, and I have to say: It has grown. It has trading, city building, realistic warfare, a complex medic system, and a whole lot of other things. There is one major issue that has been plaguing the alpha: a good portion of the game progression right now is attracting bandits and luring them to town guards. Once you have accumalated enough Cats" you can try your hand at founding a faction
recommended: then start a town. Recent updates have added more difficulty to maintaining your humble abode. Raiders will come knocking and try to extort money off of you and cannibals will invade and attempt to take you and your men to their kitchen. You can research new technology with a certain workbench

reviewText:
Early Access Review

(MAY BE A SPOILER)


I love this game, especially because of the very large battles that can take place in one area. Excluding the lag that can occur in those battles, a income that can be obtained is the loot after the battle: off of the NPCs killed. The best thing about this game is the vastness of the map! I love how there can be, say Bandits, Holy Men, and then Cannibals all fighting outside of a village.
Big problem, or maybe a little confusing/disappointing feature in this game is the money shown on NPCs that you kill around the map (what I mean is how it'll say that they have,for example, 6000 cats or money on them when you loot that character - but those 6000 cats are only pointed among their whole team put together; main problem is that the only money that you can obtain is the bounty on the leader which can be about 1000 cats).

All in all, this game is HIGHLY recommended to those who like to play strategy games in an open world, build anywhere game. ~15/10

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI have been following Kenshi for around three years now. It has grown from very basic mechanics and framework, to this very ambitious and well deserving piece of RPG interpretation. The sky is limited on what you can do now. However, the creator has been able to utilize a team to help him create the game he wants. Key features include free roaming, base building, character development and many more mechanics that make Kenshi great but also set it apart from the rest of the crowd. It has the environment and finesse that allows you to craft your own story in a very unique and different setting than a traditional RPG. It's easily the embodiment of everything a die-hard RPG fan would want to play. It's probably the Sienfeld of RPG's.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you ever want a game to succeed, you must keep your players invested. If there's anything I can say about Kenshi is that it has definitely gotten me invested in bettering my character through hours of training. The first time my bad ♥♥♥ level 50 Attack and Defense character took down an entire cannibal camp, I felt like I had truly accomplished a feat (considering how much trouble I had with them in the beginning). Watching him cleave unhindered through their bare, tattoo-ridden bodies made me so happy, albeit a bit doubtful about my sanity at the time. I can safely say that Kenshi has finally fulfilled my desire for a squad-based game in which individual progression and background really means something to me.

Now, I just want to address something that many of the backers of Kenshi have been pondering recently. Lately, Lo-Fi's been making some good progress, having implemented DX11 into the game (though it is very unstable), and added a new race and such, which is all great! But, simply said, it's still been very slow. However, I don't believe, like many people do, that this game is going too slow. In my opinion, and I feel as if people have forgotten this what with triple A games and the likes such as Star Citizen, indie developers should be slightly exempt from the time-frame criticism. I think this is especially true for a game like Kenshi, which hasn't even received that much funding. These guys need to make a living, and nagging them everyday isn't going to fix that. I guess you could say that I don't want people who are pursuing their dreams to be discouraged for going too slow.

Keep it up, Lo-Fi. I still have high hopes for this game!

Started out with one man. Recruited a partner before leaving town. Instantly beaten by bandits and then captured canibals. One man escaped and managed to amke it to the nearest town. Now i live cautiously slowly building up my people in preperation to start the biggest slaving industry i can.

I love playing this game!!!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Probably the most effective genre-busting game in its' time. It's real, -real- post-apocalyptic game that doesn't teach you anything easily and lets you figure the game out as you go, and if you're an idiot, you'll be killed. Be a smart survivor - Realize that people are absolutely insane who live in the wastelands and will likely rob you, or at the very worst, outright eat you limb by limb. - And those in the cities treat you as far as your money can throw you. . Passed that, they will let you die from starvation, don't care if you bleed out in the streets and die, may rob you - or they might  join you in your cause. . as long as you have the money to sway them.

You can be anything from a Adept Scavenger quick on their toes and trade goods for great profit between towns, to a bandit crew who massacres a farmers village for their base and all of the goods within  - whom you can trade to a fence inside a town while in a disguise as to not alert Bounty Hunters or the guards of the nation whom you've killed their subjects, to a group of settlers trying to eek out an existence amidst the wasteland and start from a lowly village to a legendary town with an abundance of food and technology new to the post-apocalyptic world. You may learn of hidden locations, if you're lucky, and encounter a plethora of characters. . Though not all are friendly.

You may be lucky and find a wandering traveler in which you can sell your goods, as well as purchase blue prints to upgrade your skill set or your very own Factional town - Of course you could just murder them and take all their goods, though you may incur a bounty that will cause you to be hunted by lawgiving police. - You could either turn yourself in and face a smaller stint in jail and/or be forced to slave away in the mines, OR you could become an infamous raider whose tales of dread are recognizable to everyone in the province. Of course,  you could always be successful noble and create your own Faction city in which all nations depend on for their trade and have the most legendary army that no one would dare question your authority. -- Or, if you were to be really ambitious, you could become an abolisher of slavery and take over the province as the rightful sire of the lands - if you're ready for hardship, effort, death, surprises, and ultimate victory.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is one of the best games I've played in a long time. If a tactical sandbox rpg combined with city building and crafting etc sounds interesting, this is the game for you.

It has a few glitches, mostly with the pathing at times but just saving and reloading usually helps.
Also I captured a bandit, put him in a bed in one of my houses and then locked the door. When he woke up and tried to get out the game crashed.. verfied this happening 3 times in a row lol, eventually I just reloaded and carried him to a cage instead.

Atm using 10+ captured bandits to train my recruits. They get their asses beaten all day long by the bandits, but some are starting to man up lol. When they are all unconscious on the floor my main character moves in to clean up and put them back in their cages.

9/10
Can't wait to see what this game will become, one of the most enjoyable early access games I know. With some polish, optimization and a few more features I could see this game becoming a masterpiece.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is early access, like super early access. It's got bugs, and issues, and crashes from time to time. But its got potential, and already has many working features.

But I love the game to bits already. Options are numerous is very custimizable, varied starting choices, even got mods!

Some people fear that this game will never be finished; that it's just a cash grab, well they're wrong. The developer has monthly updates with what they're working on, what new features, races, etc are being planned.

It's a giant endeavor, and the one single developer and a couple of hires are working as hard as possible to make updates live, but its slow work yes.

If you're looking for a complete game, get the ♥♥♥♥ out now.

But if you're looking for that something that fun that could consume hours upon hours of your time, this is it.

You're looking for that 100% open world game, this is it.

You're looking for something to hope for, to once more confirm the belief that a game in early access can become great? This is it right here.

They even got a demo if you're unsure about buying the game yet!

It'll be a slow process, but I am 100% behind this game and the developer(s)!

More information at http://lofigames.com/

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Kenshi is a RPG-RTS featuring a slow progression and massive learning curve. It's core features, being RTS battles and Dwarf Fortress-like base building, are made more complex with every patch. Though, it does lack somethings, for instance: The beginning starts you out fairly weak, even the beginnings geared towards making you more combat ready only leave you with a powerful weapon against an army of more experienced bandits.

The difficulty fluctuated heavily a few hours in though. Even after amassing an army, you still aren't strong enough to take on a single bandit party. However, when you reach a point, and you've leeched a few kills off of guards with your squad of cowards, you're able to leave the game running with no fear of attack -- or agency. I'd automated an entire camp. Random events and the like, a feature of base-building games that it emulates, would and have been a boon.

This game could easily be the greatest game I ever play -- the potential is there. I need that 3D dwarf fortress.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have been playing this game almost from the time it was GreenLit.  It is an amazing mix of RPG, RTS, City Management. Even without all the planned features implemented yet. It is still worth playing. When this game is complete, it will be one of the most awsome games to date. The developement is a little slow, but considering the size of the dev team and that they probably do most of the coding during their free time, it is understandable.  There are bugs, but you can expect that from a game in developement. The dev team is quick to address most issues or bugs as they appear.  In the end I can't stress enough, that this game is one that will provide hours and hours of game play and provide the player with the most choices in how to play. Be a lone wanderer just making his way by his sword. Lead a group of mercenaries to fame and riches. Become the most notorious bandit in the known lands, Found a city and produce goods for trade. I give this game a 9 out of 10 for being original and well developed. I hope after this project is done, the dev team continues to produce more amazing titles.

Update:
For those that like the pros and cons listed.

Pros:
1. Freedom - Explore, develope, wander, or waste your time as you please.
2. Character Developement - You gain skill when you use it. Not if you have exp to spend on it.
3. Aspect View - You can watch over from above or get into an almost 3rd person view of your party.
4. Sandbox - No pun intended. You can build a base, or even a city.
5. Swords - Lots of swords to fit your fighting styles.
6. Random - Bandit and Canibal raids. If you have a city or base, Bandits and Canibals will find you.
7. Unique - RTS meets RPG with City Management and Crafting.

Cons:
1. Pathing - Sometimes you have moving problems of your own, NPCs can get stuck for days on a rock.
2. Trading - Trading is a little hard because of the pathing issues. NPCs will get stuck trying to get to you.
3. Goals - With no ultimate goal, you can get to a point where you have to say, what do I do next. If there were a rival system. Or just a set of acheivements to get, it would add much more flavor IMO.
4. Ranged Combat - I have seen in the blogs that this is comming, but until it does, there is a chunk missing from the combat tactics.
5. Better AI - It always seems to be that there will be that one poorly armed bandit that is willing to battle it out with your band of 20 no matter what. Or the Bandits will chase one guy into a city and be swarmed with high level guards.
6. Battle Animations - There are only a limited amount of fighting animations. Hack, slash, block, can get old after a while. No evaision or anything like that.

In the end, I am hoping for a bit of polish to make this game great.  The next Update is supposed to be out soon and I can't wait.  Even with all the little frustrations and bugs.  I have had many hours of fun with this game and it has already been more than worth the $20 I paid for it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Kenshi is a unique game that is finding its niche in a mix between an RTS, Sandbox-Builder and Survival game with possible future elements of an RPG. While it's still in Alpha it is a very well polished game that offers hours of play and even more replay-ability. It's definitely not a game for the easily frustrated because you'll find yourself starting as probably the weakest character in its yet-to-be-defined universe.

Combat reflects a very realistic feel at the start: You're weak and everyone can and just about will kill you. It's a game of judging whether or not combat is really worth the possible outcome. Groups of 2-3 bandits will destroy you at the start so luring them back to larger groups is pretty much you're only option while you slowly build up the skills of your character. Having a large party will improve your odds but if they're still untrained it would be like sending a bunch of children to fight an adult. Yeah, they may overpower the adult but more than likely they'll all get beaten.

There's already several ways to make money and the economy in the game is being tweaked. This just means you don't always have to fight bandits and other patrols to get the capital necessary to start your own outpost. Then when you have that the game definitely delivers several different ways of improving your little town and building your own army.

I recommend trying this game out. There's a demo version of it available somewhere, in case you're the type worried about purchasing and not liking games still in development.

Early Access Review

This game is just simply amazing !!! even at this super early stage in alpha it is a great game alone but with all these new updates with new settings weapons, factions, and animals its going to be amazing
also i am one to research a game lots before i buy it and the Kenshi developement team has made great strides in developement and i salute them for that
this game is a realistic rpg squad based free roam where you are not the almighty hero you have to actually train and work at your characters stats for them to fight others well.
and if you want a fight you can usually find one by either going to a certain area or creating your own base(which are super in depth awesome and can be customized pretty much however you want)
once you create a base bandits will attack you and sometimes try to broker with you and will offer a deal you either pay them or they attack.
this game is just awesome every pet peave you have about other games before is fixed in this game pretty much and also one of the greatest things you can do is to leave your people on permanent jobs so you can go to sleep for 24 hours and they couldve made like 100000 loaves of bread and created the entire fort you layed out for them to build
also there are some bugs but most can be solved by simple reloading or restarting the game.
i would give this game 99.99 out of 100 stars just simply for the minimal bugs in the game

http://cdn.akamai.steamstatic.com/steam/apps/256662366/movie.184x123.jpg?t=1459357782


Once apon a time there was this guy named Captain Deathbeard, We'll call him Chris. Chris was messing with an idea of creating a physics/fighting experiement with rag doll fighters.. it was good. Then he created buildings and more NPCs.. Then clothing, Crafting, Shops and Shop Keepers, then more Towns and Outposts.. Then His one man band become 2, then 3, 4 ect ect Adding Sound, Music, New Biome development, new armours, weapons, meshes... and Now.. Creatures.. This is a unforgiving land, Everyone can and will kill you if you attack them, Bandits want your blood and so do their enemies.. oh an The Beak things & Wolves in the experimental beta.. they are hungry for anything they can eat and they can smell dead things.

If you don't own it.. your nuts! I've been on this journey following chris for a long while now and for it's price, it's bloody worth it! Get it before the price goes up and up.. I got it for like 10bucks AU years ago... worth every dollar.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you're a fan of building your own towns that span the ENTIRE GAME WORLD, leading an entire army, hardcore gameplay where if you die you die (but game doesn't end! Carry on with your community and let your previous shell rot in the sands of time!), a free roam game, or hell just swords, katanas, straw hats and ninjas, then this game is for you. It's quite unrivaled in its free roam aspects (base building / attacking towns / trading etc) despite being in an early alpha stage. You can send out different squads of people to different parts of the map, start several towns, just click on a character to move your camera to them. It'll cause quite a micromanagement hassle, as everything keeps going (unless you pause it. It features pause / x2 / x3 / x4 speeds, but lacks a notification / alert system for when people are being attacked - at the moment.) I've been enjoying and will continue to enjoy this game, with future updates sweetening the deal.

If you're a fan of real life simulators" (hardcore elements

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nIf you love town building, micro management, squad management, crafting, exploring...the list goes on, then this game is for you, this kind of game is a rare gem in my eye's, I have been a gamer for 18+ years, I have played them all, and all generes, I love this game, there is just so much to do, I was happy with the price I paid and even though this game is still in development I am having tons of fun with it, cooking, farming, looting etc etc, there are many..many factions in this game, so play as a ruthless leader and lead your followers to a life of pillaging and mayhem or be a goodie goodie like me and farm and craft and sell to your allies! this game is a sandbox so imagine the modding community it will get, I do hope it does well I would love to see future DLC., it took a little time getting used to the controls, but after about 15 mins or so I played it like a boss, I definitly recommend this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

For anyone who likes RPGs and RTS', this is the perfect combo. I absolutly love this game.
It gives alot of freedom, and the progress is good, not too fast, not too slow. Everything is learning by doing. No levels. And if you want to, you can equib a newly recruited peasant with the biggest swords and armor. Although it might not be the best choise, it does give you somewhat of an advantage.
When you do get to the point of where you have a secure foothold and a few soldiers, you reap the rewards of your labour. You see and guide your small society of people to advance and trade. And once in a while a few roaming bandits will come by, to keep your guards entertained and help with their training.
OR you can just go around being the hermit samurai and doing your best to defeat the bandits you meet, although this will mean death, if you dont have an extremly strong soldier first. And such training can be gained by follwing the traders around, as a bodyguard.

This game is a game i have been waiting for, for a long time. Its open ended. And its a perfect RPG sandbox. And its not even done yet. I recommend you to get this game, while its cheap! Its worth it already now. However, if you want a game where you can dive directly into high action, this is not the game for you. This game rewards patience and tactical gameplay.

Still in early alpha stage but already so awesome. Grow wheat and hemp, make medikits, rum, weapons, armour, roam around the huge map and start wars or trade, almost everything is (or will be) possible.

Edit:
Over a year later I don't see any improvements. Maybe some features. However performance is worse and the UI is equally (if not more) glitchy.
I saw regular updates and pictures of future races and animals and I got the idea that progress was going really fast, but based on what's actually in the game right now little seems to have changed. I'm sure there will be cool stuff in the future, but it's still far from done.
Still a lót of fun though, if you know what to look out for.
(For instance they sometimes keep walking for no reason. This could get you killed. But if you're on top of that it's no biggy)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Imagine combining Mad Max,Seven Ronin and Dune together and that's the setting of Kenshi.
You start out as a nobody.  You are not some destined saviour and have no great hidden powers.  In fact you will spend most of the beginning of the game being beaten robbed and chased all over the desert and maybe even eating by cannibals.
But what doesn't kill you in this game really does makes you stronger.   Over time you will become a formidable leader of a tribe and establish an outpost to call home.  It's a sandbox world that you will play according to your own style.

It is still very much in development by a small team and progress is slow and some builds can be unstable.  If you are patient and can stick with a long development, I think you will find a very unique game in Kenshi.  It is far from perfect, but I can not think of any other game out there like Kenshi.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

GOD I want to love this game. I really want to. I've played over 40 hours in an absurdly short amount of time trying to love it and make it work. I know it just went Beta, but this is one of the least playabe Betas (or even Alphas) I have ever taken part in.

Pathfinding is absolutely terrible. The worst of any RTS I've ever played. If you build a wall, plan on randomly getting stuck on terrain and having to deconstruct part of the wall so your resources are *poof* gone. Oh it's not over there - good luck trying to get the two parts of the walls to attach again, because there is random wall collision detection that prevents you from attaching the two pieces of the wall, so there's a good chance you'll have to start over on a huge section of wall.

There have been modest improvements to pathfinding, not least of which is your squad tries its best to use the road rather than going offroad. This seems to be a hasty workaround, because going offroad seems to get you stuck for no apparent reason a lot of the time. Also plan on reversing your path and straightening out an approach on one squad member when going through gates into cities. The devs have the best intentions by attempting the following:

- Auto-hauling
- Priority queues
- Clicking on a point on the map and having the squad automatically go there

The problem with these is the execution. Auto-hauling works alright, but you have to have a specific box for the item. For example, autohauling stone has to go to a stone box. So you're taking up a ton of space with storage boxes. This leads into priority queues, which only show 5 of the tasks you have lined up even though you can have more. So if you have 10 resources you want to haul to 10 different boxes for efficiency's sake, you won't see the 5 tasks in the bottom of the queue so you have no idea if you actually have them queued or not. So you might have to deleted and restart your entire queue if you forget.

When going to a city by selecting a point on the map, there's a good chance your squad will randomly stop and just stand there because it doesn't know where to go, even though you selected a point on the map. This map feature is very new, so I'll give it a pass. It just needs some polish. It works a lot of the time.

Whoamygod crashes. Pre .90, crashes used to be once every 5-10 minutes (so lower your Autosave threshold unless you want to constantly lose progress). Patch .90.11 made the game literally unplayable (crash shortly after load every time, regardless of whether you start a new game or not).  However, since then the crashes have gotten LOADS better. I just hope this continues.

The devs try hard (it seems) but it feels like they're playing a game of whack-a-mole. They squash a bug, another bug (or two, or three) appears in its place. I just hope to god it gets a lot more polish in the automation and pathfinding departments. Micromanaging to this degree and especially with this much frustration is not fun. If these key areas improve, this will turn a messy, bug-ridden game into a GREAT game.

All that ugliness aside... I will continue to support the game (because it's the only one of its kind really right?) and will likely change my review if there's a lot of polish. Right now it's not lookin good though.

There's the potential but nothing is done with it wich is the biggest dissappointment and this is for a while now.
I've only bought the game in hope that the money will help the dev get of there asses and maybe use another engine.
Couse this one seems like its a school assignment with the unity/ogre engine wich ruins every game i've liked so far.
Mostly these games play well in the begin but when you start to make more chars the most simple games will start to stutter!

You can make a shop but nobody comes by
You can buy food but the chars dont eat food.
You can build a city but everything needs allot of space since the paths are so buggy/crappy.
You can declare war, but nobody cares they dont come attack your town

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI've been playing for a long while now and only recently transferred my account from desura to steam, reason for my almost non-existent gameplay time...it's all about preference. All I can say is that this game is unique in its own way and a lot of reviews had gone into details which I would rather not repeat. The developer and maker of kenshi had before worked as a security guard before to make a living while designing this game until recently he got enough money from sales to form a small team. We had waited years for long intervals between updates but he had never disappointed us before. It is his persistence to complete this game, come what may attitude, is the selling point to me. I see it having a lot of potential and modable qualities, his preseverance and persistence at work is the deciding factor. Believe me, it will take some time to get a complete game but it will arrive and you will not be disappointed. It's just quality work by a single master-craftsman with a few helping hands to produce this gem, so you can't expect work to go fast to your liking....he wants it to be the best so for me, take all the time you need, just don't take too long....I hope. ^_^

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Oh my god this game. An alpha that i've consume so much hours and it's still the case to transform into weeks. The first time i saw those image and thoses tags i was like... what the hell... I MUST TRY THIS!!! and oooh boy i don't regret my choice. Kenshi is a squad based rpg where you're basicly a rat in a giant world. Depends on witch start you choose, the journey beggane with you, mostly with a pants a rusty sword, and you strove the desert to make your legend. In this game, your an ant at the very begganing. imagine that you, normal guy/guurl of all day decide to take a sword and start off you're companie. As you fight and fight, you'll learn what a true fight is. you can literraly see your character getting better at fighting. faster, wiser, deadliyer. Recruits other squad members, engineers, medics, fighter, then train and equip them : cloth, plate, mail, depends on your play style. like all plating knights style? alright. you love it fast and ninja style? alright! take what suit your play style. The fight system is an awesomly done speacking of dynamics and there is a limbs system that we can think of the fallout 3 limb system. If the Hp of a limb go to 0, either he or she won't be able to use that limb and if its a vital limb (head chest stomach) then they'll be K.O and need some medical attention. If the HP bar of thoses vital limb go to a certain negative treshold, those wounds are deadly. That's how you know that one of you mate have died in combat. This realistic mechanics also request of you to take care of your mate and leave them time to heal up, before going out and start murdering again. Go out in this majestic and awesomely well done desert. i'm totally serious here : i've passed several minutes just watching the dune, mountains and the horizon. ALOT of work as been put into the enviroment, and you feel it as soon as you have that sand in your sandals. Also, the map is ENORMOUS. Sometimes i was even saying to myself : jeez... i have to walk all that? but the reasons i'Ve just said make that you want that walking experience in this wounderful desert. Make a gigantic and prosperous town or a secret Samurai HQ, trades, fight, you really are the master of your own destiny. no missions or objective, simply survive and make a good and badass living. it's a sandbox where you do what you want and of course what you can to survive. Start off as a battleground looter to a blademaster to a rich caravan traders, to a formidable bandit or cannibal hunter, Be a bounty hunter and capture bad guys for ransom, or be the inquisitionning justicar and bring their judgment. the choice is yours. your blade awaits and the sand is thisty for blood. Get that game and start your legend!!!

P;S : sorry for the tones of grammar errors.
Have a great day wandering the dunes!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game has a ton of potential.  And I don't just say that based on the projected features, I base that on how it feels.  As I play it, I get the feeling that as development continues the game world will become a complex and interestng place, and the different facets of the gameplay will compliment it.  It is ambitious, with base building, diplomacy, squad-based tactics, and rpg elements.  If all those come together, it will be an extremely unique game.

The development is continuing steadily, it is not a project that is abandoned.  When I read about all the planned features I almost worry that the developer has bitten off more than he can chew, but the progress that has already been made proves otherwise.

As it is early access, there is not a large amount of things to do within the game world yet.  However, a significant map expansion and diplomacy/faction system are a couple of the updates coming down the pipe, and if they are as advertised this game would be justified in shedding the alpha" tag once they are released.

A couple of the game mechanics are clunky
date: it can take 5+ minutes to sell all the items in my squad's inventory due to having to run around to different merchants in the towns.  However
recommended: the game attempts to be realistic in many respects and this is one that reflects real life
hoursPlayed: a merchant likely wouldn't be able to take a dozen sets of armor off someone's hands in real life.  Although I complain about the selling system
voteText: I can see that it was purposefully done to make the game seem realistic; it is not just something that was poorly implemented or was not though through well enough.\n\nAs it is alpha
helpfulPercent: my characters do get stuck in walls occasionally
votesHelpful: it is NOT a common occurrance however.  It is easily fixable too
votesTotal: just save the game and reload with a "reset squat position" option.  This is another example of the thought put into it by the developer; he recognizes that its deveopment status could cause bugs
votesFunny: but implemented a system to allow people to enjoy their experience despite it.  And the bugs really are few and far between for me.\n\nI really think this game is going to be something special.  Aside from the planned features
commentsCount: it just has the feel of something that will be a great experience."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

In this review we will go over a few of the key features along with the pros and cons of this game. I personally am at a stand point between loving the game and distaining it while keeping in mind the game is in alpha stage. I will explain if and why this game is worth the price.

This game has been in development since 2012, the development cycle has been slow, and an update roughly every two months at the time of this review (3/14/2014) the last known update was February 10th 2014. The game has a few of the features spoken of, the vast land scape that is truly every meaning of the word large. It would take you quite some time to get across the map, I clocked it at 24 minutes on standard speed (the game comes with three speed rates) There are a few things you can do at the beginning of each game, mostly attempt to trade with other factions or cities. As most factions are less than vanilla, the rewards are arguable. You could make a living hunting bandits, or you could simply create a single structure and have the bandits come to you (After maybe 3-4 hours of excessive training). Unless of course you would like to know how it feels to be a three legged cat chased by a pack of wolves. The fighting animations are fairly nice a few clashing of swords, however does get a bit repetitive which is fine considering the game is in alpha. Now there are other things you can work to accomplish if you actually want to feel some progression in the game, consider there is no story or dialogue to guide you in the game at this time  (3/14/2014). There is however a simple tutorial in the options menu. The base building of the game is fairly nice; you can make a nifty manufacturing system mine, research and build. Then find something else to do, which of course is all there is at this current state (which is fine) as the amount of time it takes to get to that point is quite hefty. The amount of available research is quite vast, which will take you at least six to nine hours, depending on which game speed you prefer. Once you have your super industrial enterprise and have the best warriors equipped with the best weaponry and training that the game allows the next step is to find something else to do. That can be a daunting task; you could put little outposts all over the map and make your own little empire with a few squad-mates.
On another note, there are mods available for the game. The construction kit is easy to get. (http://kenshi.wikia.com/wiki/Category:Modding) Although, the amount of mods aren’t a huge attraction, but they do exist! Now then to pros of the game are.
-Awesome concept.
-Based on Sword fighting with nice animations.
-Build a small empire.
-Very large map.
-Mod-able
Now for the cons.
-Slow development.
-Many game breaking bugs.(which is forgivable for an alpha of  course)
-The game-play will come to a point where there isn’t much to do and wait for updates like many on the official forum.
-The super crash (I clocked it at every 50 minutes) Quite a few of the fellow Kenshi players know what I am talking about.
The question you need to ask yourself before purchasing is the game worth the price tag (I picked the game up for 20 dollars). The developers do need the support I will not argue that, I merely want the buyer to understand what they are getting for their hard earned cash.  As of right now (3/14/2014) the reviews for the game are quite positive, especially from the players themselves and for good reason! The amount of potential for this game is beyond words. I am personally excited about the development, and so are many others.
As a personal statement, please understand the game is in alpha stage with slow progression as most alpha stage games are just keep that in mind. If you are in doubt, watch some youtube videos on this game.
References
http://kenshi.wikia.com/wiki/Category:Modding
http://www.desura.com/games/kenshi/reviews
http://www.indiegamemag.com/alone-no-more-kenshi-goes-the-crowdfunding-route/
http://www.lofigames.com/index.php (this is their offical website.)
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pDrMcf48E9Q
