reviewText:
Early Access Review

This Review will tell the story of my first 3 Charakters.

The first one is short. I left the town and got beaten up by bandits.

The second one took way longer but is as short to tell. I left the town and built a house. Then after watching my people working for about 20 min I got bored and started a new game.

The third try I was exploring the world, hired a few followers and built another house. Then a single ninja walked by and killed all of my people.

I see a lot of potential in this game. Right now it feels too easy to just roam the map, get rich, build an army and then a settlement. I expect that to change once needs like hunger are introduced and you need to get them covered. Also I miss a lot of RPG-content. But I trust the developers that they can deliver what they planned. The game right now is quite entertaining and once they do it will be near to infinite fun.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A whole lot of fun, though a bit challenging at first. This game is overflowing with potential, and I can't wait to see where it goes.

Right now the gameplay is pretty versatile, with a number of different ways to earn money, experience, and respect. Most of these paths, e.g. farming, smithing, trading, etc. take quite a while (1-3 hours) to really get functioning, so from the getgo you've got atleast 4 or 5 hours before the game gets anywhere near the risk of being boring. Throw in random attacks from the different desert and city factions, recruiting new members from the taverns of the world, and the amazing fun of mass combat and you're looking at a game well worth the price.

Do you like Ninjas?

Have you ever wanted to play a sims type game in a ninja / samurai filled apocalyptic world?

this is the game for you, its a bit rough around the edges still, and sometimes the glitches can be quite frustrating But with the bad out of the way this game is a master class game that you should try.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Disclaimer: This game crashes. A lot. It is also buggy. It is the very definition of early access/alpha. Very rough but an amazing concept.

Now with that out of the way, let me get started. I bought this game one night after I saw it on an ad at some gaming news site. Once I started playing at about 11 pm, I looked out my window for the first time after starting playing and wouldn't you know it, the sun had come up. This game is slow paced the way I play (mind you it can be somewhat fast-paced if you're the fighting type) but holds my attention well enough that hours can pass in real time without my knowledge of it.

You start out in one of about, as it stands, six or so scenarios. You can choose to be anything from a group of six people with all the right supplies to start out with a small town wherever you choose to, or a guy in his underwear with a broken arm and a crappy pipe for a weapon starting in the middle of nowhere. From there it is your choice where to go and what to do.

Now I am the owner of quite a few early access titles here on steam, and with the exception of one game (space engineers) this game is updated the most. Lo-fi games seems to have it together and wants this title to be finished. They are also very receptive of community input. They have also said that when the game is released the price will go up, so if you're thinking about getting it but you're not sure, now is the time to buy.

If you're wondering how this game is played, which is a question I get often, then here's the best I can describe it. You order your squad around RTS style by selecting then by clicking or click and drag mouse boxing them and order them around that way. The folks in your squad however tend to be uselss in all respects when you first get them and slowly by doing different tasks (labouring, weapon/armor crafting, fighting) get better at those things, adding an rpg element to it.

Now just to wrap it up, if you buy this game, be patient and take a few hours to really get to know what you're doing before you make an opinion. Even in alpha this game is deep.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Kenshi - A RPG mixed with some tactics and base-building
Did you ever want to play a RPG where your character was not the chosen one until you achieved the skill to be him? Did you ever want to play a game where you can play with a single or multiple characters with pros and cons for each style? And most of all: Did you want a game with an open world where you can build your own outpost which can produce materials, weapons a.s.o.? If you don't mind some bugs and pathfinding problems (only sometimes) then even the alpha is good for you.

You begin with a character for whom you first choose the background. There are a few backgrounds you can choose from and each changes the difficulty (i.e. you get a better weapon or none at all, have a squad or are a loner...). So you begin on a big map (which shall get bigger as the development continues) and don't have a real goal. Except to survive. Bandits may find you very fast and the first thing you REALLY want to do is run away. You need experience. The levelling system is like in Oblivion: You get better as you do it. So now you should get to the next city or a patrol. Bandits are Bandits and you don't have the experience to fight them. Like I said: You are NOT a hero. As you venture to the towns you may find better equipment and buy it from money you got for selling looted stuff from dead bandits or ninjas. Maybe you even find better thins on them, but that does not happen very often. To get the best equipment you need to produce them on your own. As soon as you have got money and found a safe place (not too far from a city would be best) you can begin to build a research bench and begin building an outpost. It takes a lot of time. Many hours (real time, not the ingame time) until you researched everything. You also need to buy some blueprints for better weapons and armors. Now that you have even better equipment you can do more in a fight and if you already have more experience, you can take on at least 1 or 2 enemies at once. Since I only played to this point, I cannot go further with the gameplay. Oh, did I mention you can lose limbs? And need to bandage your wounds? There are no health potions and it takes a lot of time to recover.

Conclusion:
Pro:
- Huge map
- Learning by doing
- Build your own outpost/city
- Research
- Limbs can be severed
- Different weapons with different playstyle
- Research better weapons
- Not as easy as most of the games nowadays

Cons (at the moment):
- Still alpha (includes bugs and similar problems)
- No animals
- Mines can be build anywhere
- World seems very empty
- Cities are small
- Even if more guys around sometimes 1on1

Neutral:
- No AAA-gaphics, but still not so bad
- Animations

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you mainly play survival or rpg games, you may fall in love with Kenshi. If you enjoy customising a game to your own tastes or creating your own story, this is the game for you! Despite being early access and missing many of the features to be implemented in the final game, this game has so much content and so much potential. Currently, for me, the only downside is the bugs, but early access often comes riddled with bugs. Luckily the current ones don't make the game unplayable.

The pros:
-Lots of customisation
-Huge map (with bigger map in the making)
-NINJAS!
-SAMURAI!
-Solid economic and trading system
-Enjoyable combat
-Build a town/fortress/prison/camp any way you want
-Deep weapon and armour crafting system
-Custom team building (custom names, looks, armour, weapons, strengths and weaknesses)
-in-depth character customisation
-quicksave (F5) (you will be thankful if it crashes..)

Cons:
-Bugs (can be quite rare, but often frustrating. Verifying game cache can often fix the bigger bugs)
-Crashes (even more rare, mainly happen after hours of having the game open)
-TELEPORTING UNCONSCIOUS GUYS!!!

All in all, well worth the low price it is, a game with incredible potential that will suit most play styles. Recommended.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A whole lot of fun, though a bit challenging at first. This game is overflowing with potential, and I can't wait to see where it goes.

Right now the gameplay is pretty versatile, with a number of different ways to earn money, experience, and respect. Most of these paths, e.g. farming, smithing, trading, etc. take quite a while (1-3 hours) to really get functioning, so from the getgo you've got atleast 4 or 5 hours before the game gets anywhere near the risk of being boring. Throw in random attacks from the different desert and city factions, recruiting new members from the taverns of the world, and the amazing fun of mass combat and you're looking at a game well worth the price.

(Keep in mind this was written about half way through alpha testing, this game may be far ahead of what you read, by the time you see this reccomendation)

I bought this yesterday, and unlike every other Greenlight game I've seen, this one is truly amazing! I really can't express enough how great it feels to see that useless husk of a human/tribal you have, finally be able to win battles!

I at first was having great difficulty, as the games Research and a few other mechanics arent very well explained in the tutorial or help menu, but once I realized that I need blueprints, how to learn them, and how to actually stand a chance in combat the game really grew on me immensly :)

Watching your little one man army, grow to 20 men strong is really an amazing thing, and the pretty intense battles you have, really make the game amazing :)

I would definitly recommend a purchase before the price goes up as development goes on. If you're on the fence about this, I really would purchase if I were you.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

-Early Access Review-

The game of an alternative universe which is a strange mixture between apocolypse/Japan/RPG, the game where you cannot be a one man army and you actually have to work to be something useful. The game has a number of starting points for you to choose from with varied difficulty. To be honest when I first bought the game I was a little let down, the content was awkwardly done, the terrain was dull and lifeless, the pathfinding was just... horrific, base building was more than a chore and the optimisation was less than good.

Here we are now! The game has come on leaps and bounds and the developers seem to truly listen to you. We now have sound, good basebuilding mechanics, Squads that seem worthwhile (You actually feel a little heart broken if they die), pathfinding has improved although its still not quiet there and a number of new features and terrain additions have been added.

Pros:

- Interesting setting
- ALOT to do once you get the hang of it
- Buildings, lots of buildings.
- Combat is actually quite fun, nothing better than watching 40 people scrap it out over your little farm.
- I like the Everyman" (Everywoman) type of setup
- Getting chased for MILES by angry Sand Ninjas and Bandits.

Cons:
- Pathfinding and wall placement is still hit 'n' miss at times
- Getting new squad members can have you running for hours at a time
date: would love some periodic respawning\n- AI can be dumb
recommended: I had squad members watching my team die while they mined stone\n- Alot of stuff still cannot be sold which makes early game money making a case of stealing items of corpses (Vulture simulator)\n- The real lack of need for water

reviewText:
Early Access Review

9/15/2015

TL;DR at the bottom.

The Team
I have been following the development of Kenshi for almost two years now. It started with only a single creator, but as the game gained popularity, the team has expanded greatly. One of the biggest drawbacks that may push many people away from this diamond in the rough is the slow development. But while the updates may be slow, the Lo-Fi team has proven their consistancy and dedication. Updates are regular and often expected, thier website lists projects currently in the works, and the team is very responsive to the community.

The Game
Kenshi is an open-world, tactical, squad-based RPG, with a 'Sword Punk' style. It runs on the Havok engine. While a great engine, it has created significant obstacles in the way of pathfinding. However, this issue has almost completely resolved. The world has a post-catastrophic event type feel, but this may change when the giant 0.8 world update is released. Currently, the environment is a sparse desert with settlements dotting the land and bandits roaming the dunes. A faction system is present but not fully explored (you can decrease relations by attacking, increase it by healing). The art style is Jappanese influenced primarily, and the newly updated hud adds a rustic, bloody feel to it (A+).

When starting a new game, you can choose from several different scenarios, from starting with a legendary sword to a group of traders to absoloutly nothing and a bum leg. The combat is based on your characters' skills, and damage is locational.

One of the main portions of the game is base building. You can create a completely self sufficent settlement with farms, textile industry, arms crafting, and more, and traders will stop by at your stores.

Conclusion/TL;DR
Kenshi has a LOT of promise, so much that this has to be my most anticipated game currently (besides Fallout 4, of course), and has been since I bought it. It is perfectly playable as is, but gameplay can get a little dry. But having gotten 173 hours out of an early access game started by a single individual, it'd be a crime not to recommend it.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Quite honestly, this game is one the best games that I have ever played, despite being in alpha (still). The only way to even begin to describe this game would be to call the result of Age of Empires II crossed with Mount and Blade: Warband (RTS-RPG). You control your troops and build a base similarly to Age of Empires, but it is in a persistent and immersive world loosely based on feudal Japanese society, but set in a desert environment with a myriad of factions, towns, bandits and other miscellaneous NPCs to kill (or join, if you're weird like that).

Unlike M&B however, if a character dies you will lose them forever. You don't have a main" character; all your characters

recommended: and even then they are only marginally stronger than any normal person. Battles are fought in real-time with limb damage

column20: but when it is complete it will rival Skyrim and Mount and Blade as my go-to game. It may even become as revered in the minds of Steam users as Bad Rats.\n\nI do recommend buying this as soon as possible

reviewText:
Early Access Review

-Early Access Review-

The game of an alternative universe which is a strange mixture between apocolypse/Japan/RPG, the game where you cannot be a one man army and you actually have to work to be something useful. The game has a number of starting points for you to choose from with varied difficulty. To be honest when I first bought the game I was a little let down, the content was awkwardly done, the terrain was dull and lifeless, the pathfinding was just... horrific, base building was more than a chore and the optimisation was less than good.

Here we are now! The game has come on leaps and bounds and the developers seem to truly listen to you. We now have sound, good basebuilding mechanics, Squads that seem worthwhile (You actually feel a little heart broken if they die), pathfinding has improved although its still not quiet there and a number of new features and terrain additions have been added.

Pros:

- Interesting setting
- ALOT to do once you get the hang of it
- Buildings, lots of buildings.
- Combat is actually quite fun, nothing better than watching 40 people scrap it out over your little farm.
- I like the Everyman" (Everywoman) type of setup
- Getting chased for MILES by angry Sand Ninjas and Bandits.

Cons:
- Pathfinding and wall placement is still hit 'n' miss at times
- Getting new squad members can have you running for hours at a time
date: would love some periodic respawning\n- AI can be dumb
recommended: I had squad members watching my team die while they mined stone\n- Alot of stuff still cannot be sold which makes early game money making a case of stealing items of corpses (Vulture simulator)\n- The real lack of need for water
hoursPlayed:
food or anything really.


Overall a nice game

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Wow! Really got a surprise with this game.

For a beta nearing release with plenty still to be fleshed out, I give this 10 out of ten and, for once, I don't even vaguely regret the cash I spent. Fantastic game. (See Budkai's video on YouTube for a slightly dated but excellent preview.)

Kenshi is easiest described as half squad combat, half sandbox builder.

It's not at release yet but very very playable. The graphics and its engine are not spectacular but the gameplay is enthralling.

There are bugs and glitches as well as computer load and game balance issues but these are few and far between and don't stop the game being playable at all.

I definitely recommend this one!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

9/15/2015

TL;DR at the bottom.

The Team
I have been following the development of Kenshi for almost two years now. It started with only a single creator, but as the game gained popularity, the team has expanded greatly. One of the biggest drawbacks that may push many people away from this diamond in the rough is the slow development. But while the updates may be slow, the Lo-Fi team has proven their consistancy and dedication. Updates are regular and often expected, thier website lists projects currently in the works, and the team is very responsive to the community.

The Game
Kenshi is an open-world, tactical, squad-based RPG, with a 'Sword Punk' style. It runs on the Havok engine. While a great engine, it has created significant obstacles in the way of pathfinding. However, this issue has almost completely resolved. The world has a post-catastrophic event type feel, but this may change when the giant 0.8 world update is released. Currently, the environment is a sparse desert with settlements dotting the land and bandits roaming the dunes. A faction system is present but not fully explored (you can decrease relations by attacking, increase it by healing). The art style is Jappanese influenced primarily, and the newly updated hud adds a rustic, bloody feel to it (A+).

When starting a new game, you can choose from several different scenarios, from starting with a legendary sword to a group of traders to absoloutly nothing and a bum leg. The combat is based on your characters' skills, and damage is locational.

One of the main portions of the game is base building. You can create a completely self sufficent settlement with farms, textile industry, arms crafting, and more, and traders will stop by at your stores.

Conclusion/TL;DR
Kenshi has a LOT of promise, so much that this has to be my most anticipated game currently (besides Fallout 4, of course), and has been since I bought it. It is perfectly playable as is, but gameplay can get a little dry. But having gotten 173 hours out of an early access game started by a single individual, it'd be a crime not to recommend it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is one of the most ambitious games I've ever had the pleasure of playing. Kenshi is one of the reasons the gaming community will never stop dreaming, and will always have something to be excited about. It shows that one mans dream can become a reality as long as you stick to what you love. It also shows that you don't have to have millions of dollars and corporate funding to make a gem of an experience.

Now on to the meat of the review. Kenshi has come a long way since I first bought it when it first came to steam. A lot of content and technological improvements has put more meat on it bones over time, however there are some bugs and a very steep learning curve and some people might get overwhelmed with the initial difficulty. The bugs come and go mostly except for some that have lingered on and have been a real issue for some people. Like the path finding and super crashes. These bugs usually flood in when a new update comes out and they get fixed relatively quickly as time goes on. The dev does a really good job at listening to his community and the moderators and players are generally helpful and will answer any questions you have about the game. There are tons of guides and YouTube videos so if you don't understand how to do something in  the game it's pretty easy to get an issue resolved or a question answered.

This game offers many ways to play. You can be a trader, a bandit, a caravan guard, lone warrior/ wanderer, explorer, blacksmith, laborer, scientist, ninja, fragment axe wielding juggernaut. The list goes on and on, and the best thing about it is, more is going to be added in and you'll only have more ways to play the game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Imagine if Mad Max was made by Akira Kurosawa.

A desert world, bleak, hostile, vast.  Sparsely populated by junk towns and populated by newborn cultures based on old black & white samurai films, with a touch of the spaghetti westerns born thereof thrown in for good measure.  Men and women in coolie hats with katanas fighting against groups of bandits and crazed cannibals, trying to build secure outposts of safety in a violent and chaotic world.

This was the game that advertised back when I bought into it.  This was the game that was promised.  Does this sound like a great idea for a game?  Does this sound like a game that you would want to play?  Well tough crap, suckers, because all that is going bye-bye!

Welcome to a fantasy world filled with lush jungles, mysterious forrests, dangerous wolf packs, and strange races - bone men, bug men, and robots.  Oh joy, robots!  And giant monster things!  That's just what every samurai adventure needs, right?  That vast wasteland that took hours to cross is now a map ten times larger!  Why?  Because we can.  Not that you'll ever get any use out of that, but so what?

This game is no longer about wandering ronin traversing the desert in search of adventure.  It is now the living avatar of feature creep, fueled by what seems like some kind of unending mescaline binge and slowly morphing into new game entirely... a game that's only common denominator with the original is that there are swords.

And all this has been while continuing to fail at fixing bugs that are literally as old as the game itself.  Constant crashes, dysfunctional pathfinding, and broken tools thrown around like a gas explosion in a mechanic's garage.  Rather than fix the game they already had they instead decided to turn it into a RTS version of Morrowind, only weirder, if you can imagine such a thing.

Now maybe that is a game that you'd be interested in and I won't begrudge someone for liking that, but personally I don't care for the bait and switch.  I certainly do not appreciate the constant adding of more crap that I don't recall anyone asking for while everything that came before it is still horribly broken.

I saw an idea, a great idea, for a game that I would like to play.  I paid for that game.  Today I see a completely different game being made, one that I simply have no interest in, while the one I bought was never finished - and never will be.

So if you're looking for a high-fantasy, RTS version of your favorite magical wonderland, go right ahead and get Kenshi.  If you're looking for the post-apocalypse desert wandering ronin adventure originally advertised on the box then you're out of luck - keep looking, maybe someday, someone will make that game for real.

Final note: Posting this as a review since I was being banned from forum for saying the same things.  In the comments below you can read where the moderator tries to deny this.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Its like The Sims mixed with RPG.
Applies to Beta only.

Pros:
Sandbox, no restrictions in terms of free roam,
squad-base (if you like)
Settlement building
Player Choice from start
Large enough portions of the map given, very dense map that shows alot
100% player customisation, even when you add new recruits
Various mechanics that are easy to pick up (Trading, Mining, Crafting, Researching, Building)
Existing factions
Can be enhanced with mods

Cons:
Still early acess (beta) ==> long loading screen.
Crashes can occur if you right click a character if they are: sleeping on a bed, taken prisoned on a cage, don't even click on them.
Questionable AI that they are too generic, eg neutrals only fight you when provoke, enemies chase you down and nevers stops.
Quite buggy, such as clipping into grounds,
Restriction to only a small portion of a much larger scale map.

Great game, even in its beta.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I haven't seen a game with more raw potential  this early since... well, ever. It's already an addicting timesink, and I can only imagine it'll get even better as time goes on.

I love the RTS/Open-World RPG hybrid idea. Base building, squad management, character progression, and a huge world full of warring factions. reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you want a game that is so differnt from what you're used and combines your favourite elements from RPG's and RTS's, as well as some aspects of tell your own story Sims-like gameplay. Then this is certainly the game for you. However, as the devs say this game is unfinished and is still in a buggy state, your games will crash, and the frequency differs for what you are doing.

The game is fun, challenging and rewarding. I myself have got a large pack of freedom seekers that have stuck by each other through thick and thin, I've lost some along the way, but more importantly my two characters that have been together from the start are mated for life. I only wish this game had a relationship and memory system whereby the friends you make will enjoy your company and hang out, protect you and will remember the times you saved their ♥♥♥♥, and that you could show that friendship or love through interactions. Would give this game so much more life in terms of the human interaction.

This game has so much potential and I can't wait to see the finished product when it comes out of ALPHA and into BETA and then finally into full release!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game looks extremely promising.
Gameplay is amazingly good. Its a sandbox (on the sand) RPG, with heavy strategy elements.
You can be a solo adventurer or gather a group of people to fight alongside you, or even get lots of people and work to build an entire city for you.

Graphics are a bit heavy on low end PC's but meh.. we need to evolve eventually. Its 2015.

Now depending on how the story is going to be and the interaction with NPC's, this might be one of the best games so far.

Or just another preety game that we play for some time and abandon.. But sure looks very promising.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

My take on Kenshi is a mixed bag.  Bottom line is I love the game but it's horrendously buggy and development is extremely slow.

They bill it as an RPG with RTS elements, but it doesn't play that way for me.  I see it more as an RTS with RPG elements.  You scavenge materials, build a base, train recruits and laborers and defend or go on the aggressive.  It reminds me a bit of Earth 2150 in how each unit can earn experience and lvl up (the RPG aspects) while maintaining an RTS-like squad-focused feel.

It's a lot of fun training your troops and building your town up.  But the bugs, oh my.  If you play the stable" release
date: expect to crash randomly every hour or so like clockwork.  I honestly had better stability with the "experimental" opt-in steam beta branch
recommended: however some friends with similar rigs say they can't play the experimental version at all due to single digit frame-rates (it plays fine for me).  But either way you go
hoursPlayed: the sad state of pathing AI in this game really kills the joy.  Regular reloads when your own guys get stuck in the landscape and terrain and a constant spectacle of enemy units stuck on hills and corners.   This is by far the worst of the bugs
voteText: but there are lots of others.\n\nI really like the game and think it has awesome potential
helpfulPercent: but the state of development and the persistence of bugs through so many releases really has me discouraged.\n\nIf you managed to pick it up on sale like I did and don't mind risking a small investment on a game with great potential
votesHelpful: then go for it.  If you aren't willing to throw money at a project that may never be completed and has too many bugs to enjoy for any length of time in it's current state
votesTotal: then I suggest you wait and see what happens.\n\nFor me
votesFunny: I'd do it again.  I knew what I was getting into and the sale price of $10 makes it an acceptable risk."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A realy great game and worth a buy even in its early access state..

An rts/rp/sim/ninja/running/headf**k of a city building style game with alot more..

Im not gonna get into all you can do go look at youtube for that..

Great building system.
Fresh Training/leveling system (The more you do something the better you get).
Large map (All sand but new bios comming soon).
Not easy mode, if you want a squad of elite ninjas you will have to train them. rest/house them. keep them alive with medics and craft them gear and weapons.

The game will crash .... alot so get used to saving and its not so bad.
The ai tends to get stuck, stand around and do strange things but ...ya know early access.
You need to put time into this game to get the good so if your looking for an arcade style fighting ..keep looking.

But all that said i love this game and if you can look past the early access bugs buy it as its gonna be something unique.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is one of the few early access titles I've not regretted picking up early. It delievers a decent level of content already with a lot more promised on the horizon, and it actually abides by the spirit of what early access is rather than just being a sort of super early preorder; the developer actually uses community feedback to determine what features to focus on.

The game itself is also very engaging, but that's more a matter of personal preference. At its core it's primarily a sandbox game (and as far as I'm aware the first sandbox game to feature primarily desert, which strikes me as odd; think of the symbolism!), though at the moment it isn't as flexible as you'd expect a sandbox game to be. Even in early access, however, there is a decent level of easily accessible moddibility to be found. You can tweak and create weapons, NPCs, characters and even build NPC towns and modify the base mechanics of the game with a simple and relatively straightforward GUI.

There is unfortunately not much more to say about the game at this stage because it is still early access and seemingly a long way off from release, which may be enough to put a lot of people off. Let me repeat because it can't be overstated: this game is made by an incredibly small team (it was a team of one for a long time) and it isn't likely to be finished in 2014, maybe not even in 2015. But it's already a fun game at its core if you like squad based RPGs or town building simulators or a mix of both, and it is steadily progressing. I also expect that over the coming year it'll start seeing some decent modding.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A one of it's kind genre of a game. Open World RTS RPG ect ect. The work on the game is quite fast (considering the features added all the time) and was slowed down by a huge amount of work on Pathfinding, which is finally done. In the meantime, they've been adding animals, random insult generator, and all sorts of fun stuff to their dev build in preparation for the finished pathfinding. I found the game fun back in the earliest stages of alpha, without sound, great graphics, or any polish at all. It was buggy but fun then, now the bugs are fewer and the fun is far greater.

The limitations for the game are slowly getting reversed, and the game is becoming more grand by the day, with lots of dev updates and supports. The community is still small, meaning it's a lot easier to get a message across to the devs if you are feeling concerned.

Overall, this is my all time favorite strategy game, start the game with a stick and become a martial arts master who runs a fortress with well armed squad of companions who tear up all sorts of bandit life in the wastelands.

The game is great, but it's only gonna get better from here!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Kenshi
I will start by giving a brief history of my experience with Kenshi....

When I first seen this game I was ecstatic, I felt like finally an rpg like sandbox/simulation game was being developed that had a theme which I found fitting and unique. It came across as something being built upon and in a very ambitious manner. When I first jumped in kenshi I did not have much to work with other than running from town to town across this expansive desert or farming hemp. NPCs were pretty rare at this point and it did not matter much to me. I still found myself running around aimlessly, having fun just imaging what this game can eventually turn out to be. I truly believe this game has nigh endless possibility for the fans out there of this style of game play.

I have to say all in all this game is pretty self explanatory from the trailer. You can choose several starts for your character, all of which give you a different style of game play starting from a solo rp play style to a squad based one. (you can start with 1 pc or 5, you can start as a trader or retired soldier) When you get in after creating your PC you are given a rough ui with all the controls laid out in a help screen. Forewarning this is not a walk in the park, expect your survivability to be low especially when picking a tougher starting.

However, regardless of what start you end up picking you will most likly be forced to do a few monotonous things to survive. Such as having hostile npcs chase you into town, staying alive while the guards kill said hostile npcs and then looting/selling the gear you recover from them. Admittedly this is an issue, one I see being resolved as the skill and stat system is fleshed out more.

Albeit I feel as of right now, in the stage this game is currently in (alpha) it would not appeal to someone lacking the needed patience or interest in Kenshi's development. IMO - I am willing to wait as long as it takes to see this game reach it's full potential. A project of this magnitude takes time, and I hope the devs keep updating it with the slow and steady approach. This means working updates that actually change major aspects of the games mechanics, graphics, ai, landscapes...I think I have seen these guys rework or update about almost everything this game has to offer since initial release.

Updates
If you have any doubts about this game seeing updates, I would ask you to consider the following. I have been following Kenshi closely for some time and the developers are making a fantastic effort with updates. I have about 60 hrs so far putting in a few every other week since initial release. I can say the changes this game has undergone is tremendous. Here you can find any info regarding updates and the roadmap[www.lofigames.com]

Be patient and take solace in knowing you will be supporting something that does take great effort to create. The team for Kenshi is not all that lucrative afaik and the amount of work I personally have seen put in at this stage is well worth the current price tag.

Pros vs Cons(All subject to personal preference)
Pros        Cons                Price Tag        Very Long Devel Stages                Endless Possibility/Modding Support        A lot of monotony in this stage/Very Long Devel Stages                Major bugs are hot fixed fast        You Can Find A lot of bugs                Time Consuming        Time Consuming
Short of the developers studio being swallowed whole by the earth itself or losing all funding...I don't see this one not living up to it's potential. With the extent of this games mechanics and the capability of a modding community, the sky is the limit for this one. Another game that will surely, one day become a classic among the host of others.

Recommended

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'll write a short tale on how I became Hitler of Kenshi, the human experimenter.

My journey began in wanting to be the world's greatest swordsman. So naturally I studied how to increase my combat skills. It says in the description of leveling up your combat skills, such as katana, dexterity, offense, and defence to fight stronger opponents than you in order to gain a bonus in leveling them. But, the obvious problem to that is when fighting stronger opponents you run a very high risk of dying. So I took on a passive approach. In the beginning I aggroed stronger mobs into friendly cities in order to maybe get a hit in between the crossfire. After the fighting was over I looted and bandaged the mob. Then I realised something, if the mob were not armed (because I looted them) they cannot fight back. Thus I learned a faster method to grinding my skills. Every once in a while I would get hurt so I ran to the local inn and rested my injuries. There I wondered, if I can rest my body faster this way, can I rest the bad guy's bodies? Of course I can. So I started making a human farm of looted enemies where I would beat them to unconsciousness, put them on a bed, then beat them to unconsciousness when they got better. But, the story doesn't end here. Later when I was building my village I noticed I can construct prison cages. What originally started out as a simple outpost for researching weapon crafting, turned into a human livestock factory of caged samurais and holy paladins where they would be beaten to unconsciousness every momment they are awake.

tldr: I made a post-apocalyptic japanese concentration camp.

9/10 (1- for the damn glitches, go finish the game)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

my my where to begin... this game is over 9000% early access (strange bugs, horrible pathfinding, very little variety in anything, very few updates, so many unexplained crashes) and yet... it appeals to me like very few other games have. i mean when you first jump in the game is hard as diamond and as rough as sharks skin and more brutal than dark souls but i think it really sets the mood.

the game takes place on some sort of desert planet full of bandit groups, thugs for higher and shabby towns. its survival of the fittest and you better hope you and your crew are fit to survive.


Pros:
-completely open ended gameplay (you want to murder and cage every npc in a particular town? if your characters are strong enough then by all means!)

-super in depth damage system (some bandit breaks both your legs? prepare to crawl on home boy, and pray that you don't lose em!)

-build your own town/outpost (for training, crafting, and trading)

-lots of crafting to be done

-super in depth character creation (can also be used on newly recruited characters)

-indication on the hud on who is being aggroed allows the easy snapping to any battle situation no matter what you are doing with verry little load time (like if you have 3 units running weapons to a nearby town for trading when suddenly a group of bandits shows up to your town)



cons:
-some structures can not be deleted

-its not entirely clear whether or not your machines are not working because you don't have any power or they are full of junk at first glance

-some of the UI is cut off

-fast forward not fast enough (i don't want to watch my guy with broken legs carrying tons of stuff and an unconscious ally inch along the barren desert for hours looking for a town with a bed)

-beds are easily exploitable
-if you have no cash or the bed is not public you can just pick someone up and lay them on the bed and it just works
-you can place NPCs with bounties who are dying" in beds to prevent them from kicking the bucket and as an added bonus they also won't take any ♥♥♥♥ from guards who will be aggroed on them until they are removed from the bed(s)

-very peculiar bugs (one that comes to mind is my armor smith somehow getting a stack of 40000 iron plates and another stack of the same size in the container i was keeping them in when he only had time to make 40 or so of them and his AI constantly taking way more that the armor making station can hold and stopping work on armor production as a result)

-SUPER ♥♥♥♥♥♥ PATHFINDING!

- one of the towns has 2 gates however one of them is blocked by a poorly made hill or something and the pathfinding dictates that they exit the other gate and go all the way around the outer town wall just to get to where they are going.

-super steep learning curve

-amazingly slow pace

-HaVOK physics engine makes ragdolls look silly (even the dev made fun of it on twitter)

-strange bugs with carrying people some distance and later dropping them

-job allocation not clear enough (and for the longest time i didn't even know it was a thing making for a lot of tedious micro management)


if you don't mind bugs and don't have interest in any finished games at the moment: get it

if you do mind bugs or are looking at other games that are complete: go get those other games! its early access (at the time of writing this its actually in alpha) its not done and many of the cons i listed may be fixed by the time it actually comes out. so for you guys i would just wait until then."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have played over 40 hours and so far I had a nice ride.
Here´s my review:

good graphics and setup. the character design and customization is neat, although I played zoomed out most of the time anyways.

nice ideas and gameplay when it comes to base building and crafting. pretty good production chains. very nice concepts in this game.

I love the post-apocalyptic-style of world design. atmoshpere-wise this really stand out.

BUT... and there´s always a but it seems:
( i know it´s early access , I get it. I never expected a finished game. it´s not that I bught it without having experience with other EA titles.)

1. core mechanics not working or not working consistently enough
this one is my main concern. workers forget their jobs, which means you end up a lot of micromanaging individual group members.
also pathfinding and collision is a mess sometimes. even the workaround (which are offered, that´s a plus) don´t work consistently

2. slow development cycles.
the game is in development, which is nice. but so far I have experienced only one real update. the devs are in contact with the playersm which is nice. but I wonder how this game will ever pick up some momentum and gain some ground.

basically from my standpoint, i couldn´t care less about great char graphics and player customization... thats all icing on the cake once its baked and finished to eat. but pathing, collision and AI behaviour is so essential for this kind of game that it needs to get taken care of asap.

and when  Í read on the forums that some core game bugs are dependent on the actual game engine chosen for the game, I am prone to believe that maybe the have chosen the wrong engine....

its been a good expense/reward scenario for me. I don´t mind spending the money as the time I played was great. but there´s no poin fo rme in keeping playing right now, because of the points mentioned before.

keep in mind: it´s early access. so if you want to support the game and idea behind it (like I wanted to):
buy it. its a good investment as the game itself will be sweet once it´s far more advanced. whenever that might be though...

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So what is kenshi? Well, it is a sandbox RPG with a twist. It acts as an RPG in the sense that you can customize your character to almost as much detail as most other RPGs out there. You also have the crafting element you find in most RPGs and sandbox games. You may craft weapons/Armor/Clothes/medical supplies/rum (which at this stage can only be sold/food (same as rum) and other things. You gain materials to make them through mining, farming or buying it.
That is fine, so what makes kenshi different then? Well, kenshi has a couple of other elements to it, two of which add some serious sandbox/RTS attributes to it. First we have base building aspects, you may build buildings and put your production equipment and storage boxes inside. You may build walls around your town and you may put man-able crossbow and harpoon turrets on them to defend your town. Base building to a degree some RTSs don’t have, comparing it to a sandbox instead.
Now you may ask, I have a big base with lots of production equipment and I can build pretty much anything, but who is gonna run the economy??? Well, the other aspect that gives it an RTS feel is the fact that you can recruit a total number of 255 equally customized characters to your cause.
So now we have a large base and an army that may take over the world if we want? Well you will end up like that yes, but not now. Now you are one guy, and probably the weakest most insignificant one within the kenshi universe too, unable to 1v1 anything at all. That seems unfair! So at least we get a lot of gold to buy some epic swordsman to protect us right? Nope, you don’t even get that. You have crappy worthless gear and barely enough money to recruit another useless person as weak as you are, with equally worthless gear.
Okay but if 1 of my guys cant 1v1 something, maybe we can 2v1 something right? Well yes actually you may 2v1 a hungry bandit, the second weakest thing in the kenshi universe, only they don’t travel alone…there will be 10-15 of them. The only things that travel alone are the very strongest ones on the map. But that’s okay since they wont be found in the safe zone right? Wrong, the only safe zone you will find is the one you make from hard fighting and training and good gear and lots of strong fighters….In kenshi, the weak and the strong walk together, and most of the weak die before they even get a chance to grow strong. That is if you don’t wanna be stuck in a friendly town for the rest of your miserable life.
So how do we get stronger? You train your skills by using them of course. No level system, just skills that are independent of one another. For damage you increase your weapon skills, whether you wield a katana, hacker, sabre or heavy weapons class weapon is up to you. That goes along with your attack skill, which influences the frequency your attacks get passed the opponents guard. For defence you have toughness, which allows you to get hit more before fainting or dying, and is trained by…getting beat up a lot…Along with this goes your defense skill, which allows you to block or dodge more often.
Then you get your heavy supporting skills in both defense and offence, namely strength, allowing you to carry more stuff without losing speed, dexterity, increasing your attack and block speed, and athletics, increasing your movement speed.
Then you get your other skills like medic, armorer, weapons smith, thieving, stealth, laboring, engineering, science and more. Increasing your ability in each.
So how about the world, whats the world like and does everything want to kill us? Well, there are groups of bandits running around who would attack you and strip your gear once you faint(you can turn the gear stripping off if you want an easier game) ; there are ninjas running around who will attack you to train their skills, there are nests of animals who roam the area who will attack you and drag you back to their nest for feasting, there are cannibal towns who will attack you and eat you, there may be factions who hate your guts and will attack you, different towns and the groups who own them. So who do you have that will not kill you? There are traders and their guards walking from town to town, there are towns that will be neutral towards you, who luckily hate your enemies to the point where they will defend you, and there are adventurers (powerful warriors who travel solo) who will come to your aid if they are around (a rarity)
So kenshi is about learning about the world and your place in it, and slowly moving up in the world until you are the superpower. It is about skillfully avoiding unnecessary trouble until you can face it. It is about starting at the bottom, and ending at the top somehow. It is about what you have it in yourself to be. It is not multiplayer, so you wont see the horridness of humanity you find in an online community. No noob bashing and no kids acting all grown up.
Right now though the game is in alpha state, and the map is just one big desert with mountains and minimum foliage (it acts as a fake map right now since they are building the real one, which will be 339 square miles as opposed to Elder scrolls: skyrums 25) Right now it is buggy, but the devs are fixing bugs and releasing updates 2-3 times a week. The devs are very active, and have so many ideas of what they wanna add its not even funny. Right now there are 2 races, but they are planning at least 5. But for now the focus are bug fixes until they announce beta with the new world map, which will have all the kinds of biomes you can think of and more that you haven’t thought of yet, along with many biome specific creatures. There will be a fast travel system that would not work like a loading screen (or so they say) we are thinking that ships or some sort of caravan road system will be what they opt for.
Right now though, it is on steam for $19.99, where at full release $59.99 will be a bargain. This is basically an RPG/sandbox/RTS/survival game. The most complex idea I have yet seen on steam.
I would recommend it because the devs see it as a dream. They are very active and include the community in pretty much everything. Lo-Fi games, despite being a 6 man crew (half of which are not programmers) are doing an admirable job with this game. I recommend it because if the devs pull it off this will be a game easily worth more than $59.99. It may be worth close to $100, but I know that the devs wont go that far, however it is easy to see that if you buy it now, you will save lots of money. I recommend it because if the devs pull it off kenshi will be the greatest single player game in history.

So now we are at the 0.9 beta, and wow, all i can say is wow. its still buggy, but within the last 3 days a total of 9 hotfixes were released, so the team is working on it around the clock.

Weve been waiting in the deserts for what was promised to be the best single player experience ever! and we are getting closer, with the first part of the actual map being released. It looks beautiful guys, it really does. No more bare deserts, you can tell alot of effort was put into the map. There is atmosphere now, nightime seems ominous, and everyone wants you dead, or just doesnt care. Very few people would help you from being slaughtered. In the kenshi world death is just another part of life. things are harsh, and hunger is a thing now. If you dont starve, get eaten,  or killed in battle, you may just end up being that impossibly powerful swordsman you see in the movies, but even then you can die, as you are not the only one out there. The character avatars are so well designed. The stronger you get the more visible your muscles. The more starved you are the scrawnier you look. Its just great.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nWell, its nearly everything I could have wanted in a game. The RPG elements, the gradual skill increases as you perform various actions, the exploration
date:
hell, even being a character that has a backstory that suits your playstyle. The game is great with a bit of a rocky start, but after you recruit a good amount of people (at least 6-7), you can finally get things rolling with the crafting and settling of your own town- that is, if you don't choose to live in a pre-made town.

The possibilities are truly endless, and no playthrough will be the same- unless you play narrow-mindedly and safe. While I am mildly unsure as to what changes have been made to the world, the playability even through its alpha stage is marginally better than when I first bought the game. I, in fact, created my own world and recently finished it in liue of Dark Souls. The modability is there and given to you on a silver platter. All it takes is a bit of understanding, some programs, and the already there construction set and you're good to go.

Overall, I'd give Kenshi an 8/10.

Die well.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Kenshi Kenshi Kenshi... where do i begin? This game THIS GAME is my favourite game so far. (my time is low as i have a different account on my titan for different games) I play this on the train, at university, in the car i play it everywhere i can.

Take the best RPG in the world. Add a squad based strategy with a hint of banished and the fallout series and you have Kenshi..

intruged? you should be! This game is an open world do whatever you want bandit merchant and city builder simulator in a Japanese esque fallout stylee setting. When you play Kenshi you can choose your starting position. Naked and hungry with nothing on you in the middle of no-where. Do you want to be a retired captain who has made enemies of the holy empire who only has his trusty sword and the clothes on his back while the holy empire hunt him down? A group of 5 who are sick of taxes and make their own city while facing bandits and sand ninjas? Or start off in the middle of no-where with a critically injured friend in dire need of medical attention after your squad has been killed. After starting any of these starting points you can do what you want from there. Make a diplomacy with a town. join the army (well follow them it is not implemented yet) become a merchant. A bandit! or a scavenger or whatever you want! This game needs to be in your steam library NOW! This game will no doubt be a success one way or another. it has to much stuff crammed into a tiny space to not be.

What would i change in this game??

NOTHING THIS GAME IS NEARLY PERFECT
(a few glitches here and there but nothing game breaking)

So the final score...
Graphics 6/10
Gameplay 9/10
Replayability 10/10
Fun 8/10
Setting and story 9/10

Overall Score 8/10

Get this game now you will not be dissapointed =D

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis game is great, even in it's early stage. The fact that you have many start options is amazing, very few games will give you this opportunity. I must admit i started at least 20 games... At first, the Freedom Seekers, a group of 7 people with a very good stack of building materials is tempting. So you can build a farm or mine very fast. In the long run, i decided to start solo, with the trader, no cash but what you have in your backpack is enough to get you started. If you're brand new to this, google a guide for beginner, believe me, it helps... As i said previously, it's in an early stage, so you will encounter some bugs... Thank god you haven't deselect the auto-save which will save you're skin many times, believe me. The producer is updating regularly so if you encounter some new bugs, like i did, it's fixed in no time. So, overall, all good except for the camera style... I can't adjust myself to click on the middle-mouse button to rotate camera, and for some reason the camera system is only for top-bottom activity, so if you're heading to a city that's up to a moutain, you can't see it until you're almost in it, as if you were trying to see a bird in the sky, it's only top-bottom, that's mainly the only problem i see on the current version of this amazing game... Enjoy!
voteText: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis looks really solid so far, some more shortcuts for common actions would be grand, but at this pace, I see that happening soon. The visual syle and presentation are rather grand, I can really appreciate the efforts at consistency in certain areas. I'd like to see more random stuff - civilians doing things, maybe cities slowly changing, more npc interactions. But the engine is all there for these improvements, it's just a matter of adding the content itself. I really hope this game does *not* getting a debug/cheating/modding system as there is quite a lot of enjoyment in comparing progress and seeing what the game is capable of - the scale so far is EPIC. Single, squad, and city elements are all coming together so well!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As noted, Kenshi is in alpha stage, and as such should expectantly be glitchy and crashy, despite this, i have come to find myself having racked up more than 70 hours in game, and still have not lost interest. Kenshi presents fun town building and managment alongside RPG elements such as crafting, (EXTREMELY) in-depth combat and a multitude of goals to work for.
Kenshi is updated semi-regularly, and has big plans for the future. I am looking forward to seeing it progress. Must buy.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Kenshi is a game where you can do almost anything you want more freedom than most games can offer though it still has much progress the little time i played ive had loads of fun their are many pros and cons though


PROS:
-Many chracter beginnings many ones such as freedom seekers,cannibal hunters,nobodies,old soldier and a few more
-Character creation is nice needs more in depth creation hopefully another race such as mutants or something cool if there will be deserts and oceans(there is only human male and female)
-Good fighting,excellent animation with connection of blades and armor
-Challeging,this game requires much though on what you should do with a specific person and how to defeat a bandit party without having everyone becoming injured
-Graphics are nice
-Ability to stop time and look at surroundings is nice
-Good weapons and armor designs
-you get to build a base

CONS:
-Frequent crashes like i said its still in alpha so give it time and report problems
-Not enough weapon/armor choices,there should be more i reccomend no guns though could add bows too not just crossbows and dual blades and hopefully shields
-Base resources take forever(do not recommend starting out building base at all unless you pick one of the starting choices which have info on it)
-watch for your charcters being stuck
-weird trading system or merchants dont travel into outpost or leave the shop or outpost

Overrall rating is a 8.5/10 very good game nice structure,gameplay,nice graphics,good rts style gameplay if wanted and need be. DO NOT FORGET!!!!!!!!>>> Its still in alpha so give it time and try it its definatly worth the money

Early Access Review

Great game, reminds a bit at Warband, but base building is much more detailed. Early access is playable, some CTDs, some bugs but overall I've bought games where the final version was worse than this.

Lots of fun leveling up your squad, also nice tech tree for building stuff. I like that you start as an underdog and really have to act carefully in the beginning.
voteText: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nA very fun and addictive game a cross between stratergy and survival game genre. You can choose diffrent sceneries to start your story all of which add diffrent difficulties and fun to the game for example one spawns you in the middle of a camp of cannibils in which your be knocked out and have to escape, Another starts you off with a bunch of freedom seekers wanting to start their own town with a few supplies to get you started. This game adds a lot of replayability and freedom it has a few bugs here and there but it has a lot of promise and in this stage i find the game very fun and addictive.  One of my favirote features is the body health feature which if a body part gets damaged too much it will effect how you move and behave like holding your stomach from being damaged in the torso or being damaged on the leg causes you to limp which adds a dramatic feel to the game trying to limp to safety to a town or your outpost from bandits. this game still gets updated and improved on and i'm excited about seeing the future content they are lining up for this gem of a game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Kenshi is the best squad based game I have played since I started playing games. I've played it for quite some time and could recommend this game to anyone.
In it's current state Kenshi has some bugs but they will be worked out by the developers, it is most definitely worth buying and proves to be a great game to play for hours on end.
In it's current state you are able to create a base, run a trade empire or even bring law to the lands by slaughtering bandits and turning their bosses in for bounties.
Kenshi is a great game and deserves more patience from its crowd, there is no other like it and so you cannot judge it as you judge the others.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis game has come a long way from its humble beginning. Even at the early stage it was very playable. Since then more features and improvements have been made. I like the fact that the dev does not rush things and in doing so I can see this game having a very large fan base when its finally completed. Its difficult to describe this game accurately as it contains many well thought out ideas. Its a great combination of things and because death comes swiftly to the unwary you actually start to care about each individual member of your group. They are vulnerable like any human and require training and experience. As this takes time you can get quite upset should one day your group get attacked by a large group of bandits and many members die or become seriously injured. Its this level of detail that makes the game so rewarding because you have to actually think rather than just throw a bunch of disposable, easily respawned soldiers into battle as you would in other RTS games. In Kenshi a human life is a valuable commodity.

Early Access Review

If you like modding skyrim until it breaks, then Kenshi is the game for you. If you like to play your video games for only two minutes at a time, then Kenshi is for you. reviewText:
Early Access Review

My Journey so far in the experimental version
>started out as a wanderer on brisk hill, tried to lure the the bandits nearby but failed miserably so I looted the police station
>Made a Living from iron ore Mining,since looting bandits seems very unefficient and I rarely encounter them
>bought a house in the city to put storage on and a research table
>built an outpost near the river but it was soon overuned by river raptors so I abandoned it for a while
>Journeyed to Mongrel from Brisk hill, encountered several fogmen and was captured and escaped
>after escaping I was chased to mongrel Until the ninja guards killed the persuers, looted an prince hive's head and sold it
>encountered Infinity wingwang ang crumblejon, using the magic of Reloading and Reset Squad position, I teleported to brisk hill to avoid encountering the fogmen again

Overall this game provides a large amount of open world content, you can play it like a RPG or a RTS,.starting out is not easy since you are far more weaker than a Dog in the wild, there are glitches and crashes to encounter and the FPS is currently unstable with the current build, but as expected from an early access game it is still under development and new fixes and content are being added into the game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Kenshi is a sandbox, open-world game where you can theoretically do anything" however there really isn't much to do at this point.  There seems to be a lot of potential with this game but I found myself lost and bored rather quickly.  I haven't played it for very long so I will update review if anything should change.

PROS
+ Many skills to improve
+ Lots of craftable buildings and items
+ Faction system seems promising
+ Building your own base is fun

CONS
- Huge world is virtually empty
- Interface needs improvement (can't read half of it)
- Towns are bland and uninteresting (most NPCs say the same thing)
- Inventory management sucks (one piece of armor made of rags takes up HALF of my inventory?!)
- Huge learning curve with very little tutorial info (and no tooltips)
- Moving characters while manipulating camera is a pain
- Game clearly plays like an Early Access title (obviously unfinished)"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

New update. Time to change the review right?! It looks better, the camera follows your team. The world looks less like sand in your eyes and more like a setting.

Sweet right. Nope.

Still the same stupid thing happens everytime I start a game. I have a bunch of useless units who can't fight. I bump into a mob of trained killers, 30 units strong. How hard is it to set mob spawns to a game timer. Time < 40 minutes, Mob = 5. DO NOT BUY THIS GAME. IT DOESN'T WORK. IT JUST KILLS YOU OVER AND OVER AGAIN. It's not like dark souls. It's not fun, or rewarding. Your units don't get stronger. They get robbed, the get kidnapped, they get killed. There is no way to progress your units. Again. DO NOT BUY THIS GAME. Level 0 villager ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t is still real. There is still no way to prevent this. You can now pick from a bunch of races, even one with a warrior caste. Guess what. They get cut down like trash bags in the wind by 30 bandits with sticks just like your humans. While your breast size has a slider, there is still no slider for fighting skills.

Long time player same stupid flustrations.

I like the concept of this game. I can take a group of people into a hostile desert and make a civilization. What I don't like is watching dogs eat it. I don't like random groups of 30 guys with sticks knocking everyone out and walking off with them. I'm not sure what the developers play for games, maybe the sims? The group of starting colonists the game gives you all start out as level 0 village meat shields with one slightly less useless guard. Mobs are huge. The game suggests that you train all your little people in a town first, by attacking the dummies. This is a 15 minute process. Why not let me mod stats? Why not set those stats higher and skip wasting my life? Time invested versus reward is terrible. Whatever my graphic setting are at I can never see the enemy mobs coming. So suddenly 30 guys are beating my villagers to death. If they go down they need a med kit to get back up. Which you get very few of, and cost more than an arm and a leg. I wouldn't reccomend this. The play testers must all be used to doing all these stupid chores just to play or have some cheat codes. That or starting a colony got lost in the developer shuffle.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So I've been playing and following this game for about 6 months now and its seems like it has potential for a great game down the road. They say they have 30+ members to their team for development.

However, once you get past the fan boi's and get some feedback from the Devs, they are active in the forums the updates are coming in slow. I keep picking the game up and playing it, yet the bugs seem to annoy or make me put the game back down. They've spent the last 6 months polishing their experimental version, adding features, removing bugs, adding features, removing bugs but haven't released anything to the stable version which gets frusterating to say the least. Overall gameplay is 7/10, features is 4/10. Potential, 9/10. Frequency of updates 5/10.

In its current state and future potential, I'm going to give it a thumbs up but if they game slows down in development any more, it may be worth to hold off until they start polishing the game with more frequent updates.

Below is a response from a Dev/Moderator that I wasn't too fond of, if you have a questions and it can be generically answered by a moderator like below, you may see this again.

Originally posted by Captain Deathbeard:
This is what game development is like:
-You've got a list of 100 features and 100 bugs.
-Every time you add a feature, it adds another 50 bugs.
-Every time you fix 10 bugs, you discover 3 more bugs.
-Occasionally to fix one of the bugs you might need to totally restructure something. This will probably add 10 more bugs.
-When you fix bugs people say These updates don't do anything
date: where are the features?"\n-When you add features people say "Why aren't you fixing the bugs?"\n"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The best way to describe the Kenshi game world would be to think tattoine crossed with asian culture. Kenshi is a totally unique genre of game, it's a mix of RTS, RPG and Simulation but has the ability to make you feel invested in your own characters due to the random nature of the world. It's still got a while to go before the finish line but with additional content, alot of bug fixes + optimisations and more of the same passion and attention to detail that the Dev has shown so far, i have no doubt that Kenshi could wind up being one of the greatest games ever made. It's a labour of love and it truly shows. In it's current state Kenshi already has enough content to make the purchase worth the money so i whole heartedly recommend picking this game up if you want to support a Dev who's creative direction is a breath of fresh air.

Some suggestions for the Dev in the event he reads this :
- Add the ability for the camera to aim upwards not just eye level (It would be nice to be able to see up hills and see more of the stars).
- Add Bo Staffs to the Blunt weapon list when you add it in.
- The Martial arts skills in the future should be about disarming and disabling your opponents.
- Animals that act as pack mules for the travelling merchant playstyle would be great.
- Shields would be a nice addition. Much lower damage output but much higher survivability against groups swarming you.
-  Bows not just crossbows. Ranged weapons should do low damage but be more likely to cripple limbs and cause bloodloss.
- Even more weapons, armor for crafting/purchasing ect.

Anyway keep up all the great work and best of luck for the future of Kenshi!

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis game is the defintion of a perfect idea in route to a perfect game.  I have always wanted an in depth strategy game where you can forge a connection to the people in your squad and watch them grow into the certain player you need them to be.  Kenshi is a game that words cannot describe, even in its early stages it is so immense that I cannot begin to fathom trying to cram all of it into one review.  In short, kenshi is definitly a work in progress, but its also one of the most captivating, aggrivationg, emotionally taxing, in depth, fun, and addicting games I have ever had the pleasure of playing.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Overall I was suprised I enjoyed this game. Even though it is early access and a lot to be done, even though I still got addicted. I love games that allow you choose your own path and essentially start from the bottom and rise to the top. This game will become amazing once they add more features and implement a few things here and there. So if you are willing to look past bugs and limited features at the moment then this game is a lot of fun and will get you pumped to see how they make the game grow.

If you like challenging/unforgiving games (similar to Blade & Mount) then this is the game for you. Here I was lone wanderer who got attacked by a very large pack of dogs. Luckily next to a city so once I was unconcious in like 2.5 secs the guards dispatched them like chump change. I layed there (after the guards healed me) for 2 days in a recovery coma. While I figured I could reload the game I was like eh what the heck" and waited it out. This game will be challenging in the beginning. You definitely don't start out like a power house.

Graphic wise its okay. Nothing great nor terrible.

Character leveling
hoursPlayed:
and the like are fun but limited at this point in time. I can only imagine as the game gets better and adds more how it will be. You can even customize your companions once they are recruited.

Fighting is a lot like MMO's minus all the special abilities. Its point and they fight kind of thing.

As of now there are no quests but I am sure through time some will be added. As of now its just roam

reviewText:
Early Access Review

For every frustrating buggy moment I have (understandably as it's alpha) I have 100 great ones. Hyperbole maybe but my purpose is to illustrate the difference between the amazing immersion of those great unscripted moments this game supplies you with so often VS. the insignificance of the frustrating ones that occur quite rarely.

It is currently an imperfect game that is full of perfect moments. The music is right, the vibe is absolutely right, the stripped down no guidance on how to accomplish anything, while perhaps not intended for future builds, feels totally right.  You are dropped in a desolate landscape with bands of wandering thugs and brigands and tasked with figuring out how to survive. Crazy loner in a hut? Start a town with tons of followers? Just wander the waste and scavenge corpses then sell junk to NPCs? Build an armor and weapon crafting factory? Produce and sell weed and rum? All possible and you'll probably do a bit or tons of each.

The skill system is great as far as im concerned. The more you do something the better you get at said skill. Makes sense. Want to be tougher? Get beat to hell often (and recover hopefully). Want to be quicker? Run around with low encumberance. Stronger? Swing a heavy sword and wear heavy armor. Same system goes for crafting obviously.

There is zero pre generated story to be had here. If you need Bioware levels of explanation for why you're playing your game then stay away. It's 110% no direction sandbox. If you have a creative mind and sense of adventure and find creating your own backstory and narrative enjoyable then buy it. It's that simple.

Death will happen but it always feels like my fault when it does. Overconfidince or negligence is usually to blame. That being said, SAVE OFTEN. No respawns" here. You reload the last save.

Perfect blend of Samurai disciplines and the chaos of Mad Max (sans vehicles). Slow development and occasionally glitchy but I could not care less. I really hope the tiny dev team (couple people I think?) sticks with it. One of my favorite games in recent years."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I purchased this game over a year ago, and it's been fun to see how the game has progressed. Kenshi has a special place in my heart as it was my first Early Access game, and it gave way to a horrible EA addiction;

My personal views on the game:

-Being Early Access there are a number of bugs, but the majority of them are so minor as to not be noticed and tend to be fixed quickly. Overall I've only come across one bug that caused me to quit playing, but it caused me to quit for a number of months. Recently however I decided to give it another try, and I'm very happy I did, the work that the Devs have done have been amazing, and the bug had been fixed.

-The Gameplay is quite fun, albeit can be slow to get into at the start of a game, and the premise is unique, which I appriciate.

-Once the initial slow start was over I found the game to be fairly immersive, creating seperate squads, each with its own purpose, town building, guards, labor, craftsmen, bounty hunters etc.

-The Graphic are pretty good, and have improved significantly in the year I've had the game.

-Updates can come slowly, but so far have always been worth the wait.

Overall, aside from the Early Access bugs, and the occasional crash Kenshi is one of my favorite games, and I highly recommend it, however, as with all Early Access games, if you're looking for a finished game, this isn't it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Hello people, this will be a straight up review no ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t or anything like that, so here goes.

I personally like the game, it has everything that I personally want.

It's time conusming, if you want a challenge here it is, it will take you time to play and become good so you have to be willing to put it in. Great features and there are more features put into the game nearly every update. The difficulty, believe it or not, is fair but they implimented new features to make it harder or easier if you want more/less of a challenge. Your crew members will eventually die one way or another so you really do need to strategise and make sure you, yourself are 110 % convinced they will live, but that's not always the case. It used to be no sound, 1 squad max of 9 or 10, and only a certain amount you could achieve. Now, however, it is bustling with more squads, more research, tech, buildings, even mounted crossbows on walls to great giant walls. Now like I said it will take you time to achieve the perfect citadel or city but it really is worth the effort. Back bout 2 years ago I wouldn't recommend this game because it just didn't have enough in it to call it, in my opinion, alpha version.

But now I really think that this version, the alpha at the moment is worth gettiing. There is a very long play time and at the moment near endless possibilities in the game, whether just making a base, or setting impossible goals, you can achieve it.

However there are downfalls, (1st) the dev team is still relatively small making big updates slower to come out (however they are covering everything when an update does coe out), (2nd) there are very much so, alot of glitches and the AI path system is alittle stupid and annoying sometimes and the game itself can sometimes crash unexpectedly (3rd) some of the features aren't out yet which really really bugs me because they sound really cool, so there has to be a wait.

Other than that, it really is a brilliant version at the moment and I can't wait for the final release!

Happy Gaming and I hope this review was helpful and pointed you to a good purchase!
