reviewText:
Early Access Review

Kenshi has become my go-to game for sandbox aventure. The development of the game is going at the pace to be expected for such a small team. It is an ambtious project and I am confident they can pull it off.

I started as a loner in the game, forced to run for my life from town to town. Now my tribes have settled the deserts across the map. Communities of individuals capable of labor and battle. With the introduction of a slaver faction, I have taken to roaming the lands for would-be captors. Narratives will be developed from each gamer's playthrough. My point being that a story-weaving gamer will likely take great enjoyment from this game in its current state.

The game is about to undergo a major overhaul, with new biomes, an expansion of fauna varieties, and improved faction AI. At the time of this posting, there still remain pathing issues with gates and a host of bugs which are being addressed. Please keep in mind the subsequent pro/con list below is subject to adjustments as development continues.

+ Great building system and tech tree that continues to expand
+ Unit organization permits efficient distribution of tasks over many isolated towns and forts
+ High interactivity with those around you
+ Gameplay that encourages treating your community as your greatest resource
+ Open styled gameplay, I have some characters that run shops in cities while others hunt slavers. Militarism is not essential to succeed.

- Still in development, lacking much landscape and biological diversity
-                              "
hoursPlayed: as much as there are many achievements to seek in a new game

This is a game for individuals who want to see the progress of a well-made game through its evolution

reviewText:
Early Access Review

*** THIS GAME IS NOT FOR EVERYBODY, ESPECIALLY IN ITS CURRENT STATE ***

The early access boilerplate aside, if you're used to early access, this is one of steam's current gems. It is probably one of my favorite sandbox games, and my overall favorite city builder. What you get is worth your money, as long as you're willing to trudge through a few issues.

Cons -
* Not very optimized (early access)
* Rather buggy (many temporary fixes, usually nothing major)
* Occasional crashing (just remember to save)
* Some balance issues (harpoon turrets as a prime example)
* Certain starting paths don't feel full enough
* Slow updates (this is what will likely make or break for most people)

Pros -
* Very open ended sandbox
* Innovative health and damage system
* Pick, choose, and change paths
* Great city builder
* Craft virtually anything
* Plethora of different skills to train
* Still living early access game after many years in development
* (Usually) speedy bug fixing
* Very involved character creation
* Put your enemies (or friends, I don't judge) into jail cells
* Many, many more things not mentioned here.

If you enjoy sandbox, can deal with bugs and occasional crashing, don't mind being patient for updates, didn't plan on using the $20 for your next meal, and are willing to take a risk on early access, this is one of the best purchases you can make. Like I said, it isn't for everybody -- with this game, patience is key.

If it sounds like something you'd like and can tolerate, I can't recommend this enough.
voteText: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Although I bought this game back in 2013, and now it's 2015, so two years passed, the game is still Early Access. But, there are regular updates, mainly bugfixes, so it's not abandoned, and frankly I managed to put more hours in it than in most full, officially released games from big companies. I could not pinpoint why this game appeals to me so, but I think the main reason is that you can build your own town with fifty inhabitants (at least currently), which is more than most of the ingame towns can muster. Furthermore I like the combat, because it feels like combat, and most importantly you don't have to don the heaviest armor to stand a chance. Well, until you get 10-12 points in attack/defense you will bleed a lot, that's for sure, but after that you can hold your own in battle even in Adam's (or Eve's) costume. So, mainly it's the skill of the characters that counts, not their gear, which is the the contrary - fortunately - to most of other RPGs. Of course being well armored helps, but not a necessity.

I'm really curious what the game will look like when it will eventually be finished. Until then it still looks like it's a safe bet to buy it, and support the developers.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It's been about a year or so and I figure I should edit this review. The game is extremely challenging. You are NOT meant to be the chosen one, nor the best of a rag-tag bunch of guys. You are a person. You will get your ♥♥♥ kicked. A lot.

That said, your character learns from each mistake. So long as they don't die. Enemies don't really go for the kill (well... cannibals are a different story). Eventually, you and your squad might take on the world. That's the fun part. Watching them grow.

Want a hard game? Unforgiving? Kenshi is the squad RPG/RTS for you.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

6/10

Pros:
- It's definately creative, and at least in scope it goes beyond any other competing game I can think of.
- If you like a challenge then this is definately for you. At least in the beginning anyway. Once you've got your character toughened up and some production going it gets a little monotonous and you end up trying a different set of start settings.
- There's plenty of room for the players imagination. Whilst all of the features aren't there yet, give yourself a bit of a backstory and there's plenty to do.

Cons:
- As with any alpha, it's full of bugs, including numerous CTDs. I would not recommend playing it on a 32 bit system as it has loads of caching and memory issues.
- Here's the big one, appalling development team. Their site states that they've fixed things that are still broken, they refuse to give a timeline on any development, and the development progress is so slow it's unbelievable. I don't know if they can't really be bothered with it, if it's a hobby project or something else but they definately do not seem to be taking it seriously. It's a shame really, since what they have planned could really prove to be something truely fantastic.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Kenshi is what it says on the tin - a sandbox RPG. For those familiar with the Mount & Blade games, Runescape or perhaps Minecraft, there are similarities to be had here.

The game dumps you into its world with very little, and from there it is up to you. You can travel alone or start recruiting hirelings to accompany you. You can start building up your own little town, producing goods and trading, or you could go bounty hunting.

Considering it is unfinished, at time of writing Kenshi probably lacks a bit of depth to its features - there arent that many viable endgame" options for what to actually do
date: but its got definite potential and if you are a fan of the genre

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is just so absolutely amazing. Its quite an open sandbox, and has plenty of gameplay, presently, but is also heavily in development. I actually got in much, much earlier than the steam release, and it was an awesome game even then. I look forward to the improvements in the future. This is very, very much the sort of game I was hoping would be made. More and more games now get released with a pretty limited scope with some polish. This game goes with a huge scope, expanding as development progresses, and polishes as it goes. The graphical differences from the early release to now are already rather dramatic.

Seriously, I can't say how stoked I am to play the final product, feature complete.

If you are on the fence at all about getting this game, jump that fence and buy this game yesterday. Totally worth it. Easily, easily among my top 50 games, and its still in development!

I bought this game a good couple months back, i held my breath as time went on and these guys have been really consistant with thier updates ! they are pretty responsive in terms of development and theres a particular moderater hanging around here in steam and on thier website forum who's been dedicating thier time to Q & A.

I run a 32 bit system and was worried people who runs like me have been forgotten but recently they released an update for the 32 ! huzar now i can eat my piece of the cake :D, first time i jumped in i play as a retired captain went out immediately to fight some bandits there are some major noticeable changes since i last played last year and its now become more Hard, funny and enjoyable.

now after encountering bandits i bit off more than i could chew i battled with a boss bandit and defeated him but his lackeys popped round to save him, i ran back to town (micro managing the chase, quite the engaging affair if i do say so myself) but i made one wrong move and got knocked out...which then the bandits proceeded to steal my clothes the odd but funny part is that aside from the fact he took my medkit he also took my pants XD !

End conclusion these guys are consistant with most things and the game at times can be engaging almost getting the balance between rpg/rts ! i have high hopes and looking forward to the changes being made including the new races !

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a hard one. The game is amazing, it's alot of fun and has heaps of content already. The biggest problem this game has however is it's bugs. The bugs are literally everywhere, one example: i enter the game i get into character creation and i crash because my graphics settings were too high, which brings me to another problem, this game has no optimization for any graphics card, my gtx 780 ti runs overlcoked at 1150mhz in this game for some reason it only reaches 650mhz, as if the game is trying to limit my gpus potential, neverthless i still get decent framerates, which leades me to another problem, the random lag spikes which drop frame rates to 5, which leads me to tell you that you will be playing for an hour, then bug solving for the next. At least this is my current situation. I just spent 3 hours trying to get my characters to another town, because all the merchants in the town i was in bugged out and the trade screen would not show up. That's 3 hours of constant re-loads etc due to bandit attaacks killing everyone in my squad, due to lag spikes, and no matter how many reloads the merchants did not sell me anything. I now have to restart the entire game.

Do not buy this bugfest until i can go from City A to City B without restarting my game at least 3 or 4 times.


But those few hours of gaming that you manage to sneak in as the bugs gather reinforcements are truly magnificent, and because i want more money going to these devs, meaning more bug fixes i am reccommending this game. There are people complaining that the devs are focusing too much on bug fixes, they need to spend the next year fixing bugs in my opinion, the content here is good enough as it is, i merely want to enjoy the content not look at new bug-filled content if you know what i mean.

Take this review as u will, a 10/10 game, but has more bugs than the amazon.

While the game, as far as I know, is not finished yet, it shows promises.

It is long and slow for your character to get better (and I avoid saying good in purpose).

At the moment, the game does not look great, but I'm assuming all the eye candy things will make their way in eventually.

The game is unforgiving if you make mistakes (like trying to take on opponents too strong or too many of them). You might end up dying, very very very slowly, with no options to get better :).

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Be a loner, part of a small team, make an army, make a village, or a town. Or an outpost for trading. Become farmers, miners, a lot of things. You make your story and its all non-linear. Perma-death for all characters. The only way to lose is all your characters die not just the main one you start with. Or team. You can start the game with multiple characters who you can all customize to your liking. And the customization options for this game are incredible. I mean really incredible! You can change the way your characters look at any time when you hire new ones and as long as you find a plastic surgeon in a tavern in villages or cities you find and go to for the older ones. Hire as many people as you want. Right now the current stable version you can only have 20 but the final release you can have insane amounts. Train, learn, capture people, take down people with samurai swords, die from wounds loose limbs, get eaten by cannibals. Save people, help others, lay waste to towns, become bandits. Really the choice is yours.

The end game of what it may look like is close to the game series Zeno Clash. The Animals they are putting in the game resemble much of the animal life that is in those games and I love it! Currently the game is still buggy and needs more optimization but the current stable version is really good to play. If you want to try it you won't be displeased. This game is amazing!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a hard one. The game is amazing, it's alot of fun and has heaps of content already. The biggest problem this game has however is it's bugs. The bugs are literally everywhere, one example: i enter the game i get into character creation and i crash because my graphics settings were too high, which brings me to another problem, this game has no optimization for any graphics card, my gtx 780 ti runs overlcoked at 1150mhz in this game for some reason it only reaches 650mhz, as if the game is trying to limit my gpus potential, neverthless i still get decent framerates, which leades me to another problem, the random lag spikes which drop frame rates to 5, which leads me to tell you that you will be playing for an hour, then bug solving for the next. At least this is my current situation. I just spent 3 hours trying to get my characters to another town, because all the merchants in the town i was in bugged out and the trade screen would not show up. That's 3 hours of constant re-loads etc due to bandit attaacks killing everyone in my squad, due to lag spikes, and no matter how many reloads the merchants did not sell me anything. I now have to restart the entire game.

Do not buy this bugfest until i can go from City A to City B without restarting my game at least 3 or 4 times.


But those few hours of gaming that you manage to sneak in as the bugs gather reinforcements are truly magnificent, and because i want more money going to these devs, meaning more bug fixes i am reccommending this game. There are people complaining that the devs are focusing too much on bug fixes, they need to spend the next year fixing bugs in my opinion, the content here is good enough as it is, i merely want to enjoy the content not look at new bug-filled content if you know what i mean.

Take this review as u will, a 10/10 game, but has more bugs than the amazon.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is my first review for a game so I'll try to keep it brief, lol

I've put many hours into this game, and do enjoy it, though currently there is no story line, none of your actions in any way influence the world around you except when maybe the reputation system is working, which is definitely hit and miss. The pathing system still has bugs, and often times you will find people with assigned jobs stuck against something, or trying to interact with an object inside a building from the outside. I have had the game for well over a year and while updates do come out more often now (usually once every month or every two months), they still have yet to resolve really important game play issues.

I do however encourage you to purchase the game, as a fun way to pass the time inbetween games with actual story content and substance (this game currently lacks any), as the base building is fun and watching your people mow down starving bandits with turrets, who just want to attack and not steal your food, which totally refutes their name of starving bandits".

To sum it all up
date: they have some really lofty goals for the game
recommended: and if they come through with them
hoursPlayed: it will be an amazing purchase. If not you will at least have a base building game where you randomly get zerged by bandit/creature patrol
voteText: so if you are into being punished with no reward
helpfulPercent: it is definitely for you."

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI have played this game for 36 hours as of the writing of this review.  The game is buggy, but not to the point of serious irritation.  Mostly it has to do with minor pathing issues.  I have not found another game like this one.  It is a cross between an rpg, an rts, and sandbox/crafting game.  Not sure which element I like more, but one thing is certain: the game is challenging.  Always.  There is not really a point where you rest on your laurels and say, Well this is easy now."  Every new success provides the user with a new challenge.  Most of all
date: it is fun.  I highly recommend playing the "experimental Beta" rather than the more stable version of the game.  It is absolutely worth the money."

If you like the vastness of a large map, a world which is harsh and where your character has to struggle to survive, absolute randomness in the encounters and the freedom to do almost everything and to settle almost everywhere, then this is the game for you.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

There is something endearing about this game.

I purchased this game far before it was on Steam and have loved watching its continued growth. It is truly one of the handful of games I am interested in and has a charm that I find hard to describe.

I suppose I am attracted to the game because the developer made it so you are not a special snowflake in this game, you are a normal person or group of people with no special powers or abilities with the only difference from your characters and the games NPCs being your drive for success in whatever path you chose.

Any skills have to be earned and only through trial and error. You will be beaten down, your goods and clothing stolen, you will limp back with broken bones to whatever you consider safety, and then try again only to fail.
With each failure you gain experiance though and eventually you will be able to eke out a living on scraps and eventually maybe even make an outpost that could blossum into a metropolis you run, another city on the ever growing map with a whole new diplomatic game to consider. Or just be a lone wanderer trying to survive, making your own story among the sand dunes.

Possibly a true sandbox game when it eventually finishes...

+ Developer is not only active but also has an interesting personality/beard.
+ Constant updates
+ Fresh kind of gameplay
+ Future plans look bright and, more importantly, actually going to happen.

- Very Glitchy, many crashes, texture issues, shadow problems, characters getting stuck, etc (Alpha problems)
- Slow to add new content but understandable as they are focusing on getting the game more stable.
- General Alpha"ness that will go away with time

I highly recommend this game even on its current merits. The future for this game looks to be an amazing one and I can not wait to see how well it comes together."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First and formost this is an alpha review. This game is not done by a long shot so I have had glitches and errors playing this game. Also there are several aspects that I hope will be added later to make this game better. So if you will just find fault in a game that is not done I would wait and buy when it is closer to completion.

That being said I think this game is fun an different from a lot of other games out there. It does have a steep learning curve because it does not have an in game tutorial so you have to either look online or fiddle around in the game your self. This game is also not a fast pace game. It takes a long time to make your character powerful. I have seen youtube videos of people sending a solo character into a cannibal camp with about 30 or 40 cannicals and winning. I can only guess at how many hours that took them or what tricks they found to power build. starting off you cannot even fight one guy alone it seems. you will hug the cities and bring bandits to the city guards to fight and help them out. if you are willing to put in a bit of time this can be a very fun game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is the only pre-release game I've ever bought, and it was totally worth the purchase. I've already recruited a group and built an outpost. We make weapons and armor, which I sell in my outpost or take to other towns to trade. I've slowly built up my group to be adept in combat, so now we can fight off the bandits that attempt to raid our settlement rather than running to the nearest city guard for help.

I usually can't get into pure sandbox games...without a story telling me what to do I tend to feel overwhelmed and lost. Kenshi offers more gameplay options than anything else I've ever played, but there's plenty that you can do to progress the game, even though there isn't a story driving you to do X for Y.

I've built my own outpost and fortified it. I mine my own resources, make my own food, and craft my own clothing, weapons, and armor. I struggled to survive at first, but now my faction is thriving. It's a tough game at first. You aren't special. You're not a hero. Any lowly bandit could easily murder you when you start the game. But you learn to survive until you become skilled enough to defend yourself. The initial difficulty may be a turn-off for some, but it makes everything about the game so much more rewarding.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As of right now I do not feel the game is playable but if you are the kind of person that loves financing great concepts this is definitely the game to get. Kenshi is a open world action-strategy hybrid where you control one unit at the start, a character that you can gain stats with by doing natural things like running, attacking and carrying lots of weight. Sadly, it seems the game is rather barren on the 'quest' and 'story' aspects, there being pretty much nothing to do with friendly NPC's in cities besides buying supplies, getting new companions or straight up killing everybody. I am not one of those RPG 'purists' that absolutely need a story but the issue here is that as of February 14th, 2014 there is essentially no content for the player besides looking around for bandits to kill and building a base.

All of this would be fine if the games combat system worked, which it does but its painfully simply. You click on your guy and you click on your enemy and whoever has the best stats win ( Most likely your opponent at the start considering that they are pretty much always better then your character stat wise. ) There are a few unique quirks to combat like picking up wounded enemies and healing them back to health after a battle which most games dont do and I personally had the most fun doing.

Overall, as of right now I dont feel like the game is worth playing but I feel like it is a good investment for the future.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Shows great promise, still in very early alpha.

Kenishi is the story of the boy who wanted to go out into the world to become a great....Swordsman/Mayor/Trader/Inventor. But unlike most RPGs  today where the hero has all of the advantages; and magically can plow through hordes of enemies, in Kenshi, you start with the no knowledge and no skill. Almost every encounter you find at the beginning is one sided (NOT in your favor.)

Bandits roam in groups generally and your best course of action is to run. If your are caught by a group of bandits chances are you will be knocked out/killed. It is more likely your will be knocked out, in this game. This is good because this is how you learn to fight, and become tougher. But it is a pretty miserable experience trying to walk back to a city with your leg broken.

With time I think Kenishi will become one of the more interesting indie RPGs available.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First and formost this is an alpha review. This game is not done by a long shot so I have had glitches and errors playing this game. Also there are several aspects that I hope will be added later to make this game better. So if you will just find fault in a game that is not done I would wait and buy when it is closer to completion.

That being said I think this game is fun an different from a lot of other games out there. It does have a steep learning curve because it does not have an in game tutorial so you have to either look online or fiddle around in the game your self. This game is also not a fast pace game. It takes a long time to make your character powerful. I have seen youtube videos of people sending a solo character into a cannibal camp with about 30 or 40 cannicals and winning. I can only guess at how many hours that took them or what tricks they found to power build. starting off you cannot even fight one guy alone it seems. you will hug the cities and bring bandits to the city guards to fight and help them out. if you are willing to put in a bit of time this can be a very fun game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The vast majority of PC games out there follow tried and true- but cliched and tired- rules that are based on making money.  For every interesting and original concept, there are 1000 copycats who bore the living bejesus out of me, copying Warcraft or Skyrim, or some other AAA lawyer approved crud. The beancounters control what gets made, which is sad.

KENSHI is not like that. It's concepts are bold and daring, and the game is for the creative player who truly wants a sandbox without rules or carrots or narrow path pretending to be free choice.

What makes KENSHI so interesting is it's complete freedom to choose whatever role you want, whatever cardinal direction you wish to explore, and it's emphasis on a more realistic combat/character.

There is no being superman or a supreme hero in KENSHI. Expect to have your ♥♥♥ handed to you, and often, The game requires both patience and brains, which, frankly, is liable to hurt sales and frustrate the less gifted gamers out there who are accustomed to the likes of SKYRIM's mindless carrot following uber-viking nonsense.

If you want to actually succeed in KENSHI, man, you GOTTA EARN IT.

The game is tough and uncompromising, and the life of a swordsman is a brutal lesson in picking your fights, knowing when to run, and being smart enough to not succumb to greed and carry too much goods on you at once.

You need to save your money, invest in comrades in arms, and constantly, slowly, train yourself to kick ♥♥♥. That is what this game is all about, and it is almost umatchable in rewarding the player who works hard- you really feel like you earned the bad ♥♥♥ skills, once you acquire them.

Whle the game is still unpolished in looks, the basic ideas are here, and I love this game.

Things I would like to see added-

1. Formations. It's too hard to keep your tough fighters out front and your workers behind you. I'm sure it's coming, but the need for good strategic preperation before a battle in marching orders needs to be a priority.

2. More home" decorations/furniture
date: etc. Home is as inportant as adventuring and exploring. Few games remember and acknowledge this. The more home feels like home in Kenshi
recommended: the more real the characters we play will seem.\n\n3. More variety in city shops. Currently most towns feel all about the same. Each town needs one focus that makes it seem unique
hoursPlayed: in my opinion.\n\n4. More combat variety to add some uniqueness to our characters styles- dual wielding

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is the only pre-release game I've ever bought, and it was totally worth the purchase. I've already recruited a group and built an outpost. We make weapons and armor, which I sell in my outpost or take to other towns to trade. I've slowly built up my group to be adept in combat, so now we can fight off the bandits that attempt to raid our settlement rather than running to the nearest city guard for help.

I usually can't get into pure sandbox games...without a story telling me what to do I tend to feel overwhelmed and lost. Kenshi offers more gameplay options than anything else I've ever played, but there's plenty that you can do to progress the game, even though there isn't a story driving you to do X for Y.

I've built my own outpost and fortified it. I mine my own resources, make my own food, and craft my own clothing, weapons, and armor. I struggled to survive at first, but now my faction is thriving. It's a tough game at first. You aren't special. You're not a hero. Any lowly bandit could easily murder you when you start the game. But you learn to survive until you become skilled enough to defend yourself. The initial difficulty may be a turn-off for some, but it makes everything about the game so much more rewarding.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As of right now I do not feel the game is playable but if you are the kind of person that loves financing great concepts this is definitely the game to get. Kenshi is a open world action-strategy hybrid where you control one unit at the start, a character that you can gain stats with by doing natural things like running, attacking and carrying lots of weight. Sadly, it seems the game is rather barren on the 'quest' and 'story' aspects, there being pretty much nothing to do with friendly NPC's in cities besides buying supplies, getting new companions or straight up killing everybody. I am not one of those RPG 'purists' that absolutely need a story but the issue here is that as of February 14th, 2014 there is essentially no content for the player besides looking around for bandits to kill and building a base.

All of this would be fine if the games combat system worked, which it does but its painfully simply. You click on your guy and you click on your enemy and whoever has the best stats win ( Most likely your opponent at the start considering that they are pretty much always better then your character stat wise. ) There are a few unique quirks to combat like picking up wounded enemies and healing them back to health after a battle which most games dont do and I personally had the most fun doing.

Overall, as of right now I dont feel like the game is worth playing but I feel like it is a good investment for the future.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Okay.........................................THIS GAME IS GREAT, here is a list why
PROS............
1. Unlike almost EVERY game you are not the hero or best person, Kenshi makes you work hard for your place in their world.
2. The combat in the game is very grind intersive, the more you fight and land hits and block the better you become at combat.
3. For how little is majorly new in this game they're is a lot of content to wait for while they go to add a lot of content out of nowhere, suck as base building upgraded, animals, major dialouge, and even stealth.
CONS..........
1. A few bugs with hit boxes(not a major problem)
2. Maybe a little hard for people to learn.
3. Money is a little hard to come by.
4. You have to rely on npc to be able to fight and get skill early, (but combat is fun later).

Overall this game is very fun and has a great concept that I can't wait for until it is done.
9 out of 10

bought this game on the daily deal sale and i have to say i like it! it looks like it has alot of potential as im playing it in the alpha state there are a few bugs sure and the map is huge with not much way to travel and lots of sand. but watching your squad of people slug it out is sort of fun! the base building is pretty good as well i cant wait to see more option and things there and maybe some siege or attacks on the players. so for this review i would say 3/5 giving it room for improvement :)

some pro's:
the squad based fighting is cool!
the base building feature is nice fun to place a mark in the world
the fact the your units take damage to certain body parts and can bleed to death is interesting.

the cons:
the map is huge! even with the speed feature your running alot! <maybe add horses or camels to ride around?>
there is alot of sand and not much changes to it! <maybe add some weather features? it rains in the desert sometimes>
the slug fest does get bland but the game is early <i heard you may be adding some limb loss features that would be neat!>

all in all the concept behind this game is great and i cant wait to see it progress :) GL!

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nFirst off as you can see I have enough hours in this game to know what I am talking about. Not much content yet to keep you occupied for hours on end but it is getting there and fast, the game is growing in size all the time (new buildings,characters,factions and features all the time). Starting the game you will immediatly notice that the difficulty is off the charts, but that is the main goal of the game. You will quickly see your squad of 7 or os people that always lose and get beaten up by bandits turn slowly into one man armies holding up against hordes of enemies and your little settlement that started from a single shack and a mine become a thriving town with automated mines and bustling industry.And that brings us to the base building,this shows the most promise in the entire game.You can make a fortress or a simple outpost,or whatever you wish almost anywhere you wish, unfortunately the faction system is not yet implemented but when it does it is bound to be awesome. I have really high hopes and expectations from this game and as hard as it can be at times it always rewards you with a sense of achievement when your characters get off the sand,stand up dust themselves off and keep on fighting.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a game I've been following and playing for a VERY long time.  One of my first GL games, I loved the idea, the setting, and the core mechanics.  And while development seems to have been taking FOREVER (seriously, it's been in my library for over 2 years or so) it's actually been progressing very quickly, I'm just impatient.

TL;DR

Very realistic approach to an RPG game.  Nice open sandbox elements (done well so far), good combat elements that are in need of some slight refining but are otherwise well thoughtout and implemented, and the possibility to build your own bases/towns to form your own faction" is great.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I know this game has its problems, and the development has been very slow,but none the less
Kenshi is still a great experience for anyone. The dev wet from being a one man team with a part time
job several years ago. Now that the game is getting bigger the dev has hired 4 new devs to speed along the development of Kenshi.

The gameplay of Kenshi is amazing. With no story to follow you can set out on your  on or with a group and do as you will.  With half a dozen different ways to start out your adventure the replayability of this game is amazing. Kenshi  is a very unforgiving world. The first 5 playthroughs you will die soon after you begin your adventure, but when you start out the game again you will have learned from your mistakes and  keep on going and enjoy every bit of it. 10/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This Is a really amazing game that I love playing! From being able to start out completelty hopeless in a extremely dangerous desert where you can die within contact of any hostile NPC's. To the awesome level up system for your people. However the game needs work. I haven't played more than 10 hours of this game yet and already notice many things wrong with the game. I will help out by making a list of problems.
1) After closing hours of shops your person can get trapped in stores over night
2) Game crashes constantly
3) Random spawning of NPC's (litterally had a beaked giraffe or whatever it is spawn right in front of me)
4) The pathfinding is slightly broken and causes your people to loop around building before they acctually go into the one you want)
5) Textures could use a lot more work! (And I mean A LOT)
6) When youn reload the game the squad hotkey at the bottom screen does not display your characters and makes you restart the game to see it again.
7) There is no home menu option when you pause the game, WTF!
8) Characters and NPC's can walk strait through furniture
9) When your on the ground bleeding out in the middle of a town, none of the NPC's help you (This isn't really a bug or anything but come on you know it needs to be part of the game)
10) Help menu seems to be very outdated

I will update this if I run into anymore problems. But I highly recomend this game it has crazy potential to it!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

In an earlier state of the game when I first bought it, I wanted to build a base really bad. I chose to build it somewhat close to a dogs den on a hill, next to the mountain because it looked like a defensible location. I thought it was far enough from the dog's aggro range.

I was wrong. Day after day, dogs practically rushed up the hill and murdered my squad in their sleep. Sometimes, it rained dogs on top of my squad member's heads. One @#$%ing dog could completely destroy my whole squad, even with some  members clad in heavy plate armor. Just to build a well, they even had to go on stealth mode for fear of alerting the dogs.

After constant fighting and brushes with death, my squad members survived and grew stronger. There were times when I had them running up the hill with huge backpacks packed with heavy ores, concrete bricks and water buckets just to train their strength.

Eventually, I had at least 3 warriors on par with a samurai lord, and could solo sweep the entire murderous dog's den on their own. I was unrivalled across much of the land of Kenshi, and even won a battle with an entire city's worth of policemen". Good times.

Based on past experiences
date: I recommend building your base next to a monster spawn."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Woke up in the middle of the desert at a cannibal camp. Tried to fight them, got rekt. Squad enclosed in a cage for 2 days. Managed to lock pick my way out while the cannibals are fighting giant ostrichs in the North and Starving Bandits in the South.

Some other dudes were in cages too, I helped them get out and in return they helped us fight the remaining cannibals in the camp.

I managed to kill 30 cannibals with a 5 man squads, slowly but surely, just for the purpose of training them.

Cleared out the area, times to move on . My squad is slow, most of them are badly hurt, one of them is KO, I need to carry him to the nearest town which is pretty ♥♥♥♥ing far away. I can't run, it's going to be a difficult trip.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

That's just an exemple of what is happening in Kenshi. The developpers builded a very unique universe and gameplay. If you want an original and quite hardcore experience in a game Kenshi is what you need.

There is no goal, you might want to build a base, create a huge army with 4 squads of 10 mens, get some backpack and travel around the map to trade goods, etc.

Starting in Kenshi is pretty slow and you might want to go for the Freedom Seekers" start which gives you a decent sized squad and a bunch of building materials to start a base.

The developpers are working hard on a Beta release that should be happening end of March (probably April tbh) with a better map and a bunch of content.

Right now the game is buggy and crash a lot
date:
hopefully we will see some improvement after the Beta release when they start working on fixing everything.

I suggest anyone to give a try. Keep in mind that you'll have a hard time when starting. You should try to bait enemies in cities to get the help of the Police (which is OP) when training your squad to fight.

Also you'll need beds to recover quicker
recommended: but you won't have any money at first to make them or rent them in town
hoursPlayed: one way of going around this problem is to pick up your allys and put them in the hotel's beds in town
voteText:
you won't get charged for the bed if you do so.

tl;dr
Great game
helpfulPercent: lot of potential
votesHelpful: already a good amount of content. Crashs a lot
votesTotal: wait for Beta if that pisses you off."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

(Due to bad internet, I've got much less hours on record than I've actually played)

I'm updating my review, which was made in 2014.

I still recommend this game. Since my purchase of it, it has been updated, patched onto and received many additions. That, however, does not make it complete, or stable.

What are you getting right now?

The game is a survival sandbox-rpg where you command a squad of people with different skills and attributes, you can build in a vast, albeit a bit empty (a new map is coming, so... not an issue), desert land; mine; trade; hunt for bandits, for trade caravans; research and manufacture an assortment of products, from food, to booze, to katanas, to chain mail.

There are several cities and settlements, a couple of factions, ranging from bandits to the holy nation, to cannibals, and slavers.

As it is, the game is filled with half implemented features, grayed-out options, bugs and optimization issues and, basically, room for improvement.

It also comes with a lot of things to do, from building a fort, to making a ton of money from trade, to beating the ever living crap out a bandit boss who wanted to threaten you and sticking him in a cage, only to then hand him in to some samurai police dude.

tldr

The game is not ready, but has been being updated, and, overall, has improved since my acquisition of it. In addition, it is great fun to have such a degree of freedom in a game, and I have full confidence in the developers and their commitment to their product, which is key to an early access game.

If anything, the year and a half I've had with this game taught me that regardless of the goals the devs set themselves, they seem quite capable of achieving it, should you give them time.

Buy this game if you enjoy watching a game evolve and develop.  DO NOT BUY THIS GAME IF YOUR WANTING A PERFECT GAME OUT THE GATE!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

TL;DR pros and cons:

+ Awesome game (unique style, interesting design, great gameplay etc.etc.)
+ They did it to beta, yay!
~ Seemless blend of RTS and a Town-builder on a solid RPG foundation.
~ Tru sandbox (no story-quest-line, just sand, your toys and your imagination)
~ Game is mod-able so you can add a sexy-armor, i guess...
~ Currently being heavily tested, so expect instability and weird bugs
- Horrible optimisation at this point, but issue is being adressed, and WIP.


NTL;WR (Not Too Long; Will Read):


Synopsis:

First of all, i have to say that the game's description and videos are quite accurate and trustworthy. Pay a close attention to the game's description, by the way. First goes free-roaming" then "squad-based" and only then "RPG". While it is indeed an RPG
date: in the same time it's not
recommended: or at least - not wholly and not in a usual way.\nYou character(s) has a set of stats and set of skills that could be raised in some ways. You can equip your character(s) with whatever gear is accessible out there
hoursPlayed: in any combination possible. You can tune out the phisical appearance of your character(s) in any given way. Basically
voteText: you can build your character(s) whatever you want in every possible meaning.\nBut that's where our usual "RPG" ends.\nIn Kenshi nobody will give you a story and send you to an epic quest. Not even a minor quest. Not even to gather 5 rat skulls or deliver a love letter or wake up 11 guards. NPCs won't unwrap their soul to you in a complicated system of carefully thought-out dialogues with dozens of possible outcomes. You can't get married. You can't even woo anybody

reviewText:
Early Access Review

TL;DR pros and cons:

+ Awesome game (unique style, interesting design, great gameplay etc.etc.)
+ They did it to beta, yay!
~ Seemless blend of RTS and a Town-builder on a solid RPG foundation.
~ Tru sandbox (no story-quest-line, just sand, your toys and your imagination)
~ Game is mod-able so you can add a sexy-armor, i guess...
~ Currently being heavily tested, so expect instability and weird bugs
- Horrible optimisation at this point, but issue is being adressed, and WIP.


NTL;WR (Not Too Long; Will Read):


Synopsis:

First of all, i have to say that the game's description and videos are quite accurate and trustworthy. Pay a close attention to the game's description, by the way. First goes free-roaming" then "squad-based" and only then "RPG". While it is indeed an RPG

Not even a minor quest. Not even to gather 5 rat skulls or deliver a love letter or wake up 11 guards. reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI bought this game in the Steam Summersale 2013. I played it for a while and discovered that it was an unplayable mess, even for an alpha. 18 months later I tried again, thinking that maybe some of the bugs have been fixed and that the game would have some interesting content instead of just an empty desert. I don't know what the developer(s?) did between those months time, but actually trying to make a game was not one of them. Virtually no progress had been made and I am convinced that this junkheap of a game will never ever actually be anywhere near finished.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Save your money. There is absolutely no gameplay in this game.

Combat is right clicking, sitting back and watching, there is no challenge or skill, just grind.

It's advertised like a samurai mount&blade with base building. What it really is, is a barrel landscape with nothing to do.
99% of the map is a barren mountainous desert with no features besides towns you can visit. You start out with a weak guy, and then you decide what to do from there. Maybe appropriate for people that play D&D or minecraft, happy to pay money for a blank slate for you to paint your own picture. But if you've paid to be entertained, you would get more value out of a chocolate bar.

I promised myself never to buy into alpha games, after getting ripped off buying towns, now I remember why. This game is the next abandonware project I've mistakenly paid into thanks to an impulse frontpage 40% off sale.
voteText: 8 of 18 people (44%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game has a lot of potential, however I am not sure they will take it on.
Early game: Early game last a very long time, partially because it is difficult to get skilled out of early game.
This part of the game is boring, repitition and grants no sense of doing anything.  You go find a group of baddies, lead them to town, help the guards fight (if you call it help), loot and sell, buy guys and gear, repeat for hours.

Mid game: After you have enough guys, lets say 20 to be safe, you can buy up a bunch of building material, find a spot and start your own town.  Hopefully you can win about 20-30% of the fights by now.  This is where the game starts to get interesting finally.  Unfortunately I started this too soon, unable to actually win most fights makes my 12 guys unable to hold up my base.

Short of it:  The game is as grindy as an MMO, but makes winning more difficult at first.  Based on the description, I believe it will become too easy late in game, if I could get to that point.  Thus I believe the mid-game is about the only part with any play value, considering how long it takes to get to that point I would not suggest starting again with a new goal unless you like watching guards grind.

With the description by the Developer the world will not change, hense long game you'll be so tough it will be boring from the lack of challenge.  This is why I don't believe the game will ever reach it's potential, and why I cannot recommend it.
